ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¬ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ 31 July 2010\n(http://www.webcommunities-conf.org/)\npart of the IADIS Multi Conference on Computer Science and Information Systems (MCCSIS 2010)\nFreiburg, Germany 26 ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¬ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ 31 July 2010 \n(http://www.mccsis.org)\n\n\n* Keynote Speaker (confirmed):\nProfessor Wang Lu, Department of Educational Technology, Capital Normal University, China\n\n* Conference background and goals\nThe mission of this conference is to publish and integrate scientific results and act catalytically to the fast developing culture of web communities. The conference invites original papers, review papers, technical reports and case studies on WWW in particular the emerging role of so-called WWW-Based Communities.\n\n* Format of the Conference \nThe conference will comprise of invited talks and oral presentations. The proceedings of the conference will be published in the form of a book and CD-ROM with ISBN, and will be available also in the IADIS Digital Library (accessible on-line).\n\n* Best Papers\nSelected authors of best papers will be invited to submit extended versions of their papers to selected journals (i.e. IADIS International Journal on Computer Science and Information Systems - ISSN: 1646-3692) including journals from INDERSCIENCE Publishers.\nThe better papers will be candidate for the "International Journal of Web Based Communities" (IJWBC); ISSN: 1477 - 8394 [4 issues per year].\n\n* Types of submissions \nFull and Short Papers, Reflection Papers, Posters/Demonstrations, Tutorials, Panels and Doctoral Consortium. All submissions are subject to a blind refereeing process.\n\n* Topics related to Web Based Communities are of interest. These include, but are not limited to the following areas and topics: \n\nThe history, architecture and future of virtual communities\n1. From mobility to connectivity \n2. Identity and augmented ideologies \n3. Visionary web architectures, implanted computers \n4. Network revolutions, post-colonial and post-modern societies \n5. Escaping from reality, virtual reality and multi-user games \n6. Towards alternative ways of presence \n \nGroup processes and self-organization\n1. Tele-democracy, morality, netiquette \n2. Social networks, tribal- and open communities, peace education \n3. Computer mediated-, hyper- and narrative communication, woven stories \n4. MUDs, MOOs and avatars \n5. Hosting web-based communities \n6. Nationalities, ethnicities and gender effects \n \nCyborgs, teleworking, telemedicine, art games and learning communities \n1. Fading hierarchies and epistemic dictatorship \n2. Distributed cognition, the electronic cortex and constructivism \n3. Community directories \n4. Mechanic world, organic computer \n5. Agents and the vectorized self \n6. Beyond metaphors: imagining and representation \n7. Communizing as a marketing approach \n \nExpanding markets through virtual communities\n1. The WWW as digital market place \n2. The enterprise as a learning community \n3. The learning as a road map for business \n4. Universities as online communities \n5. Business-to-business communication in profit- and non profit sectors \n \nVirtual communities for people with special needs\n1. Access to public spaces \n2. Accessibility and long-term disabilities \n3. Virtual communities in health care \n\n* Important Dates:\n- Submission Deadline (new date): 15 March 2010\n- Notification to Authors (new date): 12 April 2010\n- Final Camera-Ready Submission and Early Registration (new date): Until 7 May 2010\n- Late Registration (new date): After 7 May 2010\n- Conference: Freiburg, Germany, 29 31 July 2010\n\n* Conference Location \nThe conference will be held in Freiburg, Germany. \n\n* Secretariat \nIADIS Secretariat - IADIS INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE WEB BASED COMMUNITIES 2010\nRua Sao Sebastiao da Pedreira, 100, 3 \n1050-209 Lisbon, Portugal \nE-mail: secretariat@webcommunities-conf.org\nWeb site: http://www.webcommunities-conf.org/\n\n* Program Committee \nWeb Based Communities 2010 Conference Program Co-Chairs:\nPiet Kommers, University of Twente, The Netherlands\nPedro Albert-Ludwigs-UniversitÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¤t Freiburg [Apologies for cross-postings, Please send to interested colleagues and students, -- CALL FOR PAPERS - Deadline for submissions (new date): 15 March 2010 --, IADIS INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¬ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ 31 July 2010, (http://www.webcommunities-conf.org/), part of the IADIS Multi Conference on Computer Science and Information Systems (MCCSIS 2010), Freiburg, Germany 26 ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¬ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ 31 July 2010 , (http://www.mccsis.org), * Keynote Speaker (confirmed):, Professor Wang Lu, Department of Educational Technology, Capital Normal University, China, * Conference background and goals, The mission of this conference is to publish and integrate scientific results and act catalytically to the fast developing culture of web communities, The conference invites original papers, review papers, technical reports and case studies on WWW in particular the emerging role of so-called WWW-Based Communities., * Format of the Conference , The conference will comprise of invited talks and oral presentations, The proceedings of the conference will be published in the form of a book and CD-ROM with ISBN, and will be available also in the IADIS Digital Library (accessible on-line)., * Best Papers, Selected authors of best papers will be invited to submit extended versions of their papers to selected journals (i.e, IADIS International Journal on Computer Science and Information Systems - ISSN: 1646-3692) including journals from INDERSCIENCE Publishers., The better papers will be candidate for the "International Journal of Web Based Communities" (IJWBC); ISSN: 1477 - 8394 [4 issues per year]., * Types of submissions , Full and Short Papers, Reflection Papers, Posters/Demonstrations, Tutorials, Panels and Doctoral Consortium, All submissions are subject to a blind refereeing process., * Topics related to Web Based Communities are of interest, These include, but are not limited to the following areas and topics: , The history, architecture and future of virtual communities, 1, From mobility to connectivity , 2, Identity and augmented ideologies , 3, Visionary web architectures, implanted computers , 4, Network revolutions, post-colonial and post-modern societies , 5, Escaping from reality, virtual reality and multi-user games , 6, Towards alternative ways of presence , , Group processes and self-organization, 1, Tele-democracy, morality, netiquette , 2, Social networks, tribal- and open communities, peace education , 3, Computer mediated-, hyper- and narrative communication, woven stories , 4, MUDs, MOOs and avatars , 5, Hosting web-based communities , 6, Nationalities, ethnicities and gender effects , , Cyborgs, teleworking, telemedicine, art games and learning communities , 1, Fading hierarchies and epistemic dictatorship , 2, Distributed cognition, the electronic cortex and constructivism , 3, Community directories , 4, Mechanic world, organic computer , 5, Agents and the vectorized self , 6, Beyond metaphors: imagining and representation , 7, Communizing as a marketing approach , , Expanding markets through virtual communities, 1, The WWW as digital market place , 2, The enterprise as a learning community , 3, The learning as a road map for business , 4, Universities as online communities , 5, Business-to-business communication in profit- and non profit sectors , , Virtual communities for people with special needs, 1, Access to public spaces , 2, Accessibility and long-term disabilities , 3, Virtual communities in health care , * Important Dates:, - Submission Deadline (new date): 15 March 2010, - Notification to Authors (new date): 12 April 2010, - Final Camera-Ready Submission and Early Registration (new date): Until 7 May 2010, - Late Registration (new date): After 7 May 2010, - Conference: Freiburg, Germany, 29 ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¬ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ 31 July 2010, * Conference Location , The conference will be held in Freiburg, Germany, * Secretariat , IADIS Secretariat - IADIS INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE WEB BASED COMMUNITIES 2010, Rua Sao Sebastiao da Pedreira, 100, 3 , ...] IADIS INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE WEB BASED COMMUNITIES 2010 {'15 March 2010': '- submission deadline (new date): 15 march 2010', 'July 2010': '- conference: freiburg, germany, 29 ãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâ¢ãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâ¢ãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâ¬ãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâ¢ãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâãâ 9 CLEF 2010 - Conference on Multilingual and Multimodal Information Access Padua, Italy Call for Papers\r\n\r\nCLEF 2010 - Conference on Multilingual and Multimodal Information Access\r\nEvaluation\r\n\r\n20ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¬ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ23 September 2010, Padua, Italy\r\n\r\nhttp://www.clef2010.org/\r\n\r\n\r\nBackground\r\n\r\nCLEF2010 is the continuation of the popular CLEF campaigns that have run for\r\nthe past ten years. It will cover a broad range of issues in the fields of\r\nmultilingual and multimodal information access evaluation. It will consist\r\nof two main parts: a peer-reviewed conference (20-21 September) on\r\nexperimental evaluation, which will innovate the CLEF tradition, and a\r\nseries of labs (22-23 September), which will continue the CLEF tradition of\r\ncommunity-based evaluation and discussion on evaluation issues.\r\n\r\n\r\nAim and Scope\r\n\r\nThe CLEF2010 conference aims at advancing the evaluation of complex\r\nmultimodal and multilingual information systems in order to support\r\nindividuals, organizations, and communities who design, develop, employ, and\r\nimprove such systems.\r\n\r\nThe growth of the Internet has been exponential with respect to the number\r\nof users, media, and languages used regularly for global information\r\ndissemination. Language and media barriers are no longer seen as inviolable\r\nand they are constantly crossed and mixed to provide content that can be\r\naccessed on a global scale within a multicultural and multilingual setting.\r\n\r\nUsers need to be able to co-operate and communicate across language and\r\nmedia boundaries, going beyond separate search in diverse media/languages\r\nand exploiting interactions between different languages and media.\r\n\r\nExperimental evaluation - both laboratory and interactive - is a key to\r\nfostering the development of multilingual and multimodal information systems\r\nthat address increasingly complex information needs.\r\n\r\nThe CLEF2010 labs will continue the CLEF tradition of community-based\r\nbenchmarking and will complement these with workshops on emerging issues in\r\nevaluation methodology. Lab proposals were sollicited at an earlier stage\r\nand and the 2010 lab program can be found at http://www.clef2010.org/. \r\n\r\nAt this time we invite submissions for presentation at the CLEF2010\r\nconference. We welcome submissions on all aspects of multilingual and\r\nmultimodal information access evaluation. All submissions will be reviewed\r\non the basis of relevance, originality, importance, and clarity.\r\n\r\nThe conference proceedings will be published in the Springer Lecture Notes\r\nin Computer Science (LNCS) series.\r\n\r\n\r\nTopics for Discussion\r\n\r\nRelevant topics for CLEF 2010 include, but are not limited to:\r\n\r\n- Novel methodologies for the design of evaluation tasks, especially\r\nuser-centric ones;\r\n- Analysis of the impact of multilingual/multicultural/multimodal\r\ndifferences in interface and search design;\r\n- Assessing multilinguality and multimodality in relevant application\r\ncommunities, e.g. digital libraries, intellectual property, medical, music,\r\nvideo, and social media.\r\n- Alternative methods for improving and automating ground-truth creation,\r\nfor example crowd-sourcing or clicklog-based;\r\n- Prediction of success and satisfaction rates;\r\n- Task-oriented metrics of success and failure;\r\n- Evaluation of technology vs testing of scientific theories;\r\n- Innovative and easy to communicate techniques for analysing the\r\nexperimental results, including statistical analyses, data mining, and\r\ninformation visualization;\r\n- Alternatives for and comparison of item-based, list-based, set-based, and\r\nsession-based evaluation;\r\n- Simulation (of queries, sessions, users) and information retrieval;\r\n- Infrastructures for bringing automation and collaboration in the\r\nevaluation process;\r\n- Component-based evaluation approaches;\r\n- Evaluation and analysis using private or anonymized test data;\r\n- Living laboraties and evaluating live systems.\r\n\r\n\r\nImportant Dates \r\n\r\n- Submission Deadline: 2 May 2010\r\n- Notification of Acceptance: 11 June 2010\r\n- Camera Ready: 25 June 2010\r\n- Conference: 20-21 September 2010.\r\n\r\n\r\nFormat\r\n \r\nAuthors are invited to submit electronically original papers, which have not\r\nbeen published and are not under consideration elsewhere, using the LNCS\r\nproceedings format\r\n(http://www.springer.com/computer/lncs?SGWID=0-164-7-72376-0).\r\n\r\nTwo types of papers are solicited:\r\n- long papers: 12 pages max;\r\n- short papers: 6 pages max.\r\n\r\nPapers will be peer-reviewed by at least 3 members of the program committee.\r\nSelection will be based on originality, clarity, and technical quality. \r\n\r\nPapers should be submitted in PDF format to the following address:\r\nhttp://www.easychair.org/conferences/?conf=clef2010\r\n\r\n\r\nOrganization\r\n\r\nHonorary Chair\r\n- Carol Peters, ISTI-CNR Pisa, Italy\r\n\r\nGeneral Chairs\r\n- Maristella Agosti, University of Padua, Italy\r\n- Maarten de Rijke, University of Amsterdam, The Netherlands\r\n\r\nProgramme Chairs\r\n- Nicola Ferro, University of Padua, Italy\r\n- Alan Smeaton, Dublin City University, Ireland\r\n\r\nOrganization Chair\r\n- Emanuele Pianta, CELCT Trento, Italy\r\n\r\n\r\nProgram Committee\r\n\r\n- Eneko Agirre, University of the Basque Country, Spain\r\n- Giambattista Amati, Fondazione Ugo Bordoni, Italy\r\n- Julie Berndsen, University COllege Dublin, Ireland\r\n- Pia Borlund, Royal School of Library and Information Science, Denmark\r\n- Pavel Braslavski, Yandex and Ural State Tech. University, Ural State\r\nUniversity, Russia\r\n- Chris Buckley, Sabir Research, USA\r\n- PÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¡vel Calado, Superior Technical Institute, Portugal\r\n- Tiziana Catarci, Sapienza, University of Rome, Italy\r\n- Stefano Ceri, Politecnico di Milano, Italy\r\n- Charlie Clark, University of Waterloo, Canada\r\n- Bruce Croft, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, USA\r\n- Franca Debole, Institute of Information Science and Technologies (ISTI),\r\nItalian National Research Council (CNR) , Italy\r\n- J. Stephen Downie, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, USA\r\n- Susan Dumais, Microsoft Research, USA\r\n- Floriana Esposito, University of Bari, Italy\r\n- Marcello Federico, Fondazione Bruno Kessler, Italy\r\n- Norbert Fuhr, University of Duisburg, Germany\r\n- Fredric Gey, University of California, Berkeley, USA\r\n- Marcos AndrÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ© September, 2010, ,, Padua, ,, Italy, \r\n\r\n, http://www.clef2010.org/, \r\n\r\n\r\n, Background, \r\n\r\n, CLEF2010, is, the, continuation, of, the, popular, CLEF, campaigns, that, have, run, for, \r\n, the, past, ten, years, ., It, will, cover, a, broad, range, of, issues, in, the, fields, of, \r\n, multilingual, and, multimodal, information, access, evaluation, ., It, will, consist, \r\n, of, two, main, parts, :, a, peer, -, reviewed, conference, (, 20, -, 21, September, ), on, \r\n, experimental, evaluation, ,, which, will, innovate, the, CLEF, tradition, ,, ...) Italy [Call for Papers, CLEF 2010 - Conference on Multilingual and Multimodal Information Access, Evaluation, 20ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¬ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ23 September 2010, Padua, Italy, http://www.clef2010.org/, Background, CLEF2010 is the continuation of the popular CLEF campaigns that have run for, the past ten years, It will cover a broad range of issues in the fields of, multilingual and multimodal information access evaluation, It will consist, of two main parts: a peer-reviewed conference (20-21 September) on, experimental evaluation, which will innovate the CLEF tradition, and a, series of labs (22-23 September), which will continue the CLEF tradition of, community-based evaluation and discussion on evaluation issues., Aim and Scope, The CLEF2010 conference aims at advancing the evaluation of complex, multimodal and multilingual information systems in order to support, individuals, organizations, and communities who design, develop, employ, and, improve such systems., The growth of the Internet has been exponential with respect to the number, of users, media, and languages used regularly for global information, dissemination, Language and media barriers are no longer seen as inviolable, and they are constantly crossed and mixed to provide content that can be, accessed on a global scale within a multicultural and multilingual setting., Users need to be able to co-operate and communicate across language and, media boundaries, going beyond separate search in diverse media/languages, and exploiting interactions between different languages and media., Experimental evaluation - both laboratory and interactive - is a key to, fostering the development of multilingual and multimodal information systems, that address increasingly complex information needs., The CLEF2010 labs will continue the CLEF tradition of community-based, benchmarking and will complement these with workshops on emerging issues in, evaluation methodology, Lab proposals were sollicited at an earlier stage, and and the 2010 lab program can be found at http://www.clef2010.org/, At this time we invite submissions for presentation at the CLEF2010, conference, We welcome submissions on all aspects of multilingual and, multimodal information access evaluation, All submissions will be reviewed, on the basis of relevance, originality, importance, and clarity., The conference proceedings will be published in the Springer Lecture Notes, in Computer Science (LNCS) series., Topics for Discussion, Relevant topics for CLEF 2010 include, but are not limited to:, - Novel methodologies for the design of evaluation tasks, especially, user-centric ones;, - Analysis of the impact of multilingual/multicultural/multimodal, differences in interface and search design;, - Assessing multilinguality and multimodality in relevant application, communities, e.g, digital libraries, intellectual property, medical, music,, video, and social media., - Alternative methods for improving and automating ground-truth creation,, for example crowd-sourcing or clicklog-based;, - Prediction of success and satisfaction rates;, - Task-oriented metrics of success and failure;, - Evaluation of technology vs testing of scientific theories;, - Innovative and easy to communicate techniques for analysing the, experimental results, including statistical analyses, data mining, and, information visualization;, - Alternatives for and comparison of item-based, list-based, set-based, and, session-based evaluation;, - Simulation (of queries, sessions, users) and information retrieval;, - Infrastructures for bringing automation and collaboration in the, evaluation process;, - Component-based evaluation approaches;, - Evaluation and analysis using private or anonymized test data;, - Living laboraties and evaluating live systems., Important Dates , - Submission Deadline: 2 May 2010, - Notification of Acceptance: 11 June 2010, - Camera Ready: 25 June 2010, - Conference: 20-21 September 2010., Format, , Authors are invited to submit electronically original papers, which have not, been published and are not under consideration elsewhere, using the LNCS, proceedings format, (http://www.springer.com/computer/lncs?SGWID=0-164-7-72376-0)., Two types of papers are solicited:, - long papers: 12 pages max;, - short papers: 6 pages max., Papers will be peer-reviewed by at least 3 members of the program committee., Selection will be based on originality, clarity, and technical quality, Papers should be submitted in PDF format to the following address:, http://www.easychair.org/conferences/?conf=clef2010, Organization, Honorary Chair, - Carol Peters, ISTI-CNR Pisa, Italy, General Chairs, - Maristella Agosti, University of Padua, Italy, - Maarten de Rijke, University of Amsterdam, The Netherlands, Programme Chairs, - Nicola Ferro, University of Padua, Italy, - Alan Smeaton, Dublin City University, Ireland, Organization Chair, - Emanuele Pianta, CELCT Trento, Italy, ...] CLEF 2010 - Conference on Multilingual and Multimodal Information Access {'September 2010': '- conference: 20-21 september 2010.', '20-21 September': 'of two main parts: a peer-reviewed conference (20-21 september) on', '22-23 September': 'series of labs (22-23 september), which will continue the clef tradition of', 'May 2010': '- submission deadline: 2 may 2010', '11 June 2010': '- notification of acceptance: 11 june 2010', '25 June 2010': '- camera ready: 25 june 2010'}
10 Fifth IEEE International Workshop on Practical Issues in Building Sensor Network Applications Denver, CO, USA IEEE SENSEAPP 2010\nThe Fifth IEEE International Workshop on Practical Issues in Building Sensor Network Applications\nCalling for papers\n\nIntroduction:\nSensor nodes are tiny autonomous devices that combine sensing, computing and wireless communication capabilities. These nodes are deeply embedded into the physical surroundings, and gather and process information such as temperature, humidity, light characteristics, seismic activities or images and sound samples from the physical world. Networked systems of such sensors are expected to be used in a variety of applications including habitat monitoring, precision agriculture, disaster recovery operations, healthcare and supply chain management. Real world sensor network deployments and prototype implementations are still not commonplace. However, experiences gained in such deployments are crucial for the sensor network research community. These results will allow us to refine assumptions made when designing hardware, software, protocols and mechanisms for sensor networks.\n\nSenseApp 2010, the Fifth IEEE International Workshop on Practical Issues in Building Sensor Network Applications, will be a one-day workshop, held in conjunction with the IEEE Conference on Local Comupter Networks (LCN 2010). The workshop aims at bringing together researchers from academia and industry to showcase their work and obtain feedback. We expect the workshop to act as a forum for the sensor network research community to discuss open issues, novel solutions and the future development of wireless sensor networks in general.\n\nScope:\nAuthors are invited to submit original unpublished work, not currently under review by another conference, workshop or journal. Full papers should be restricted to 8 camera-ready pages (in 10 pt font, double column, US letter size, 8.5 x 11 inches, IEEE format) including text, figures and references. Poster papers are an opportunity to present initial results and obtain feedback on on-going research. We also welcome submissions for demonstrations that showcase original research, practical implementations and realistic applications of wireless sensor networks. Poster/demo papers must be restricted to 2 camera-ready pages. Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:\n\nExperiences from real-world sensor network deployment and applications\nInnovative sensor network applications\nMiddleware support for sensor networks\nProgramming and debugging sensor networks\nSecurity, availability and dependability issues in sensor networks\nPractical problems in implementing localization and time synchronization\nExperiences with communication protocols\nPractical medium access control protocols (MACs)\nTopology control and routing protocols in existing sensor network deployments\nAntenna design and experiences with signal propagation\nExperiences regarding energy management and network lifetime\nFault-tolerance and troubleshooting sensor networks\nManagement of large-scale sensor networks\nInterconnection between IP and sensor networks\nHardware design and operating systems issues\nConfiguration and installation support\nParticipatory sensing\n\n\nSubmitted papers will be reviewed by three independent experts in the field. Proceedings of the workshop will be published together with those of IEEE LCN, and will be available in digital format from the IEEE Explore Digital Library.\nImportant Dates:\nPaper Registration Deadline: 15 May 2010\nPaper Submission Deadline: 22 May 2010 \nNotification of Acceptance: 6 July 2010\nCamera Ready Copy Due: 28 July 2010\nAuthor Registration by: 28 July 2010\nConference start: 11 October 2010 (IEEE, SENSEAPP, 2010, \n, The, Fifth, IEEE, International, Workshop, on, Practical, Issues, in, Building, Sensor, Network, Applications, \n, Calling, for, papers, \n\n, Introduction, :, \n, Sensor, nodes, are, tiny, autonomous, devices, that, combine, sensing, ,, computing, and, wireless, communication, capabilities, ., These, nodes, are, deeply, embedded, into, the, physical, surroundings, ,, and, gather, and, process, information, such, as, temperature, ,, humidity, ,, light, characteristics, ,, seismic, activities, or, images, and, sound, samples, from, the, physical, world, ., Networked, systems, of, such, sensors, are, expected, to, be, used, in, a, variety, of, applications, including, habitat, monitoring, ,, precision, agriculture, ,, disaster, ...) Sensor [IEEE SENSEAPP 2010, The Fifth IEEE International Workshop on Practical Issues in Building Sensor Network Applications, Calling for papers, Introduction:, Sensor nodes are tiny autonomous devices that combine sensing, computing and wireless communication capabilities, These nodes are deeply embedded into the physical surroundings, and gather and process information such as temperature, humidity, light characteristics, seismic activities or images and sound samples from the physical world, Networked systems of such sensors are expected to be used in a variety of applications including habitat monitoring, precision agriculture, disaster recovery operations, healthcare and supply chain management, Real world sensor network deployments and prototype implementations are still not commonplace, However, experiences gained in such deployments are crucial for the sensor network research community, These results will allow us to refine assumptions made when designing hardware, software, protocols and mechanisms for sensor networks., SenseApp 2010, the Fifth IEEE International Workshop on Practical Issues in Building Sensor Network Applications, will be a one-day workshop, held in conjunction with the IEEE Conference on Local Comupter Networks (LCN 2010), The workshop aims at bringing together researchers from academia and industry to showcase their work and obtain feedback, We expect the workshop to act as a forum for the sensor network research community to discuss open issues, novel solutions and the future development of wireless sensor networks in general., Scope:, Authors are invited to submit original unpublished work, not currently under review by another conference, workshop or journal, Full papers should be restricted to 8 camera-ready pages (in 10 pt font, double column, US letter size, 8.5 x 11 inches, IEEE format) including text, figures and references, Poster papers are an opportunity to present initial results and obtain feedback on on-going research, We also welcome submissions for demonstrations that showcase original research, practical implementations and realistic applications of wireless sensor networks, Poster/demo papers must be restricted to 2 camera-ready pages, Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:, Experiences from real-world sensor network deployment and applications, Innovative sensor network applications, Middleware support for sensor networks, Programming and debugging sensor networks, Security, availability and dependability issues in sensor networks, Practical problems in implementing localization and time synchronization, Experiences with communication protocols, Practical medium access control protocols (MACs), Topology control and routing protocols in existing sensor network deployments, Antenna design and experiences with signal propagation, Experiences regarding energy management and network lifetime, Fault-tolerance and troubleshooting sensor networks, Management of large-scale sensor networks, Interconnection between IP and sensor networks, Hardware design and operating systems issues, Configuration and installation support, Participatory sensing, Submitted papers will be reviewed by three independent experts in the field, Proceedings of the workshop will be published together with those of IEEE LCN, and will be available in digital format from the IEEE Explore Digital Library., Important Dates:, Paper Registration Deadline: 15 May 2010, Paper Submission Deadline: 22 May 2010 , Notification of Acceptance: 6 July 2010, Camera Ready Copy Due: 28 July 2010, Author Registration by: 28 July 2010, Conference start: 11 October 2010] The Fifth IEEE International Workshop on Practical Issues in Building Sensor Network Applications {'May 2010': 'paper submission deadline: 22 may 2010 ', '6 July 2010': 'notification of acceptance: 6 july 2010', '28 July 2010': 'author registration by: 28 july 2010', '11 October 2010': 'conference start: 11 october 2010'}
11 4th International Workshop on Large Scale Distributed Systems and Middleware Zurich, Switzerland CALL FOR PAPERS - LADIS 2010\r\n\r\nThe 4th International Workshop on\r\nLarge Scale Distributed Systems and Middleware\r\n\r\nZurich, Switzerland, 28-29 July 2010\r\nHeld in conjunction with PODC\r\nIn cooperation with SIGOPS pending approval\r\n\r\nhttp://www.cs.cornell.edu/projects/ladis2010\r\nOn Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/ladisworkshop\r\n\r\nABOUT THE WORKSHOP\r\n\r\nLADIS 2010 will bring together researchers and practitioners in the\r\nfields of distributed systems and middleware to discuss the\r\nchallenges of building massive distributed computing systems and\r\nclouds. By posing research questions in the context of the largest\r\nand most-demanding real-world systems, LADIS serves to catalyze\r\ndialog between cloud computing engineers and scalable distributed\r\nsystems researchers, to open the veil of secrecy that has surrounded\r\nmany cloud computing architectures, and to increase the potential\r\nimpact of the best research underway in both the systems and theory\r\ncommunities.\r\n\r\nDue to the co-location with PODC, this year's LADIS will devote\r\nspecial attention to promoting exchange of ideas between the theory\r\nand systems communities on the topics related to design,\r\nimplementation, performance and underlying principles of large-scale\r\ndistributed systems and cloud computing.\r\n\r\nThis workshop invites work and promotes the exchange of ideas in the\r\nfollowing topics:\r\n\r\n- Consistency, reliability and fault-tolerance models for cloud\r\n computing infrastructures and the technologies to support them\r\n (e.g. convergent consistency, transactions, state-machine\r\n replication).\r\n\r\n- Novel storage organizations for large scale systems (e.g., no-SQL\r\n databases or key-value storage), snapshot and weak isolation\r\n models, scalable and elastic transaction approaches\r\n (e.g. mini-transactions), wide-area transactions.\r\n\r\n- Large-scale infrastructure technologies (e.g. Chubby, Paxos,\r\n Zookeeper, group membership services, distributed registries).\r\n\r\n- Support and programming models for scalable cloud-hosted\r\n applications and services (e.g. map-reduce, global file systems,\r\n pub-sub, multicast, group communication).\r\n\r\n- Power and other resource management tools (e.g. virtualization and\r\n consolidation, resource allocation, load balancing, resource\r\n placement, routing, scheduling).\r\n\r\n- Privacy tools and models (e.g. digital identity management,\r\n encrypting private data in the cloud, information flow in data\r\n centers).\r\n\r\nParticular attention is given to challenges unique to the\r\nlarge-scale distributed systems and cloud computing domains.\r\n\r\nThe workshop will last for a day and a half, which will include a\r\nmix of presentation of accepted papers and as well as keynotes from\r\nprominent industry speakers who have been there, made key decisions,\r\nand can talk about the architectures of the world's most demanding\r\ncloud platforms.\r\n\r\nPrevious LADIS keynote and invited speakers include Gennaro Cuomo\r\n(CTO, IBM WebSphere), Jeff Dean (Google Fellow), James Hamilton\r\n(technology guru for Microsoft's Cloud Computing initiative, now at\r\nAmazon), David Nichols (Microsoft Windows Live), Raghu Ramakrishnan\r\n(Yahoo! Fellow), Ben Reed (developer of Yahoo's Zookeeper), Marvin\r\nTheimer (Principal Engineer at Amazon), Franco Travostino and Randy\r\nShoup (CTO and Chief Architect for eBay).\r\n\r\nSUBMISSION AND LOGISTICS\r\n\r\nTo attend, you are invited to submit a position or short research\r\npaper expressing new ideas, research directions, or relevant\r\nopinions. Submissions consist of up to 5 pages using 11-point Times\r\nRoman font, including title page with author names, and\r\nbibliography. Submissions deviating from these guidelines will not\r\nbe reviewed. Submissions will be judged on originality, clarity,\r\nrelevance, and, above all, their likelihood of generating\r\ndiscussion. Accepted papers will be published in the ACM Digital\r\nLibrary.\r\n\r\nIMPORTANT DATES\r\n\r\nPaper Submission: 1 May 2010\r\nNotification: 15 June 2010\r\nCamera-ready due: 5 July 2010\r\nWorkshop Date: 28-29 July 2010\r\n\r\nGENERAL CHAIRS\r\n\r\nGregory Chockler, IBM Research, Haifa, Israel\r\nYmir Vigfusson, IBM Research, Haifa, Israel\r\n\r\nPROGRAM CHAIRS\r\n\r\nMarcos K. Aguilera, Microsoft Research, USA\r\nMarc Shapiro, INRIA & LIP6, France\r\n\r\nPROGRAM COMMITTEE\r\n\r\nPeter Dickman, Google, Switzerland\r\nDanny Dolev, Hebrew U., Israel\r\nAmr El Abbadi, UC Santa Barbara, USA\r\nAlan Fekete, U. Sydney, Australia\r\nSeth Gilbert, EPFL, Switzerland\r\nRicardo JimÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ©nez Peris, U. PolitÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ©cnica Madrid, Spain\r\nFlavio Junqueira, Yahoo Research, Spain\r\nDahlia Malkhi, Microsoft Research, USA\r\nChristine Morin, IRISA, France\r\nYasushi Saito, Google, USA\r\nIon Stoica, UC Berkeley, USA (CALL, FOR, PAPERS, -, LADIS, 2010, \r\n\r\n, The, 4th, International, Workshop, on, \r\n, Large, Scale, Distributed, Systems, and, Middleware, \r\n\r\n, Zurich, ,, Switzerland, ,, 28, -, 29, July, 2010, \r\n, Held, in, conjunction, with, PODC, \r\n, In, cooperation, with, SIGOPS, pending, approval, \r\n\r\n, http://www.cs.cornell.edu, /, projects, /, ladis2010, \r\n, On, Twitter, :, http://www.twitter.com/ladisworkshop, \r\n\r\n, ABOUT, THE, WORKSHOP, \r\n\r\n, LADIS, 2010, will, bring, together, researchers, and, practitioners, in, the, \r\n, fields, of, distributed, systems, and, middleware, to, discuss, the, \r\n, challenges, of, building, massive, distributed, computing, systems, and, \r\n, clouds, ., By, posing, research, questions, in, the, context, of, the, largest, ...) Switzerland [CALL FOR PAPERS - LADIS 2010, The 4th International Workshop on, Large Scale Distributed Systems and Middleware, Zurich, Switzerland, 28-29 July 2010, Held in conjunction with PODC, In cooperation with SIGOPS pending approval, http://www.cs.cornell.edu/projects/ladis2010, On Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/ladisworkshop, ABOUT THE WORKSHOP, LADIS 2010 will bring together researchers and practitioners in the, fields of distributed systems and middleware to discuss the, challenges of building massive distributed computing systems and, clouds, By posing research questions in the context of the largest, and most-demanding real-world systems, LADIS serves to catalyze, dialog between cloud computing engineers and scalable distributed, systems researchers, to open the veil of secrecy that has surrounded, many cloud computing architectures, and to increase the potential, impact of the best research underway in both the systems and theory, communities., Due to the co-location with PODC, this year's LADIS will devote, special attention to promoting exchange of ideas between the theory, and systems communities on the topics related to design,, implementation, performance and underlying principles of large-scale, distributed systems and cloud computing., This workshop invites work and promotes the exchange of ideas in the, following topics:, - Consistency, reliability and fault-tolerance models for cloud, computing infrastructures and the technologies to support them, (e.g, convergent consistency, transactions, state-machine, replication)., - Novel storage organizations for large scale systems (e.g., no-SQL, databases or key-value storage), snapshot and weak isolation, models, scalable and elastic transaction approaches, (e.g, mini-transactions), wide-area transactions., - Large-scale infrastructure technologies (e.g, Chubby, Paxos,, Zookeeper, group membership services, distributed registries)., - Support and programming models for scalable cloud-hosted, applications and services (e.g, map-reduce, global file systems,, pub-sub, multicast, group communication)., - Power and other resource management tools (e.g, virtualization and, consolidation, resource allocation, load balancing, resource, placement, routing, scheduling)., - Privacy tools and models (e.g, digital identity management,, encrypting private data in the cloud, information flow in data, centers)., Particular attention is given to challenges unique to the, large-scale distributed systems and cloud computing domains., The workshop will last for a day and a half, which will include a, mix of presentation of accepted papers and as well as keynotes from, prominent industry speakers who have been there, made key decisions,, and can talk about the architectures of the world's most demanding, cloud platforms., Previous LADIS keynote and invited speakers include Gennaro Cuomo, (CTO, IBM WebSphere), Jeff Dean (Google Fellow), James Hamilton, (technology guru for Microsoft's Cloud Computing initiative, now at, Amazon), David Nichols (Microsoft Windows Live), Raghu Ramakrishnan, (Yahoo! Fellow), Ben Reed (developer of Yahoo's Zookeeper), Marvin, Theimer (Principal Engineer at Amazon), Franco Travostino and Randy, Shoup (CTO and Chief Architect for eBay)., SUBMISSION AND LOGISTICS, To attend, you are invited to submit a position or short research, paper expressing new ideas, research directions, or relevant, opinions, Submissions consist of up to 5 pages using 11-point Times, Roman font, including title page with author names, and, bibliography, Submissions deviating from these guidelines will not, be reviewed, Submissions will be judged on originality, clarity,, relevance, and, above all, their likelihood of generating, discussion, Accepted papers will be published in the ACM Digital, Library., IMPORTANT DATES, Paper Submission: 1 May 2010, Notification: 15 June 2010, Camera-ready due: 5 July 2010, Workshop Date: 28-29 July 2010, GENERAL CHAIRS, Gregory Chockler, IBM Research, Haifa, Israel, Ymir Vigfusson, IBM Research, Haifa, Israel, PROGRAM CHAIRS, Marcos K, Aguilera, Microsoft Research, USA, Marc Shapiro, INRIA & LIP6, France, PROGRAM COMMITTEE, Peter Dickman, Google, Switzerland, Danny Dolev, Hebrew U., Israel, Amr El Abbadi, UC Santa Barbara, USA, Alan Fekete, U, Sydney, Australia, Seth Gilbert, EPFL, Switzerland, Ricardo 12 The 1st International Conference on Pervasive Networked Services and Internet of Things Chongqing, China :::::::::::: A CALL FOR PAPERS ::::::::::::::::::::::::::\nThe 1st International Conference on Pervasive Networked Services and Internet of Things\n12-14th July 2010\nChongqing, PRC\n\n\nBackground\n\nPervasive computing is emerging as the next paradigm for distributed and mobile computing through building systems of communicating miniaturized devices, sensors and actuators in which ambient, personalized trustworthy services built out of pervasive infrastructure and information are seamlessly available anywhere, anytime, and in all forms. By embedding ambient intelligence in everyday objects, our workplaces, our homes and even ourselves, pervasive computing and communications will enable a new breed of applications and systems which are composed of massive smart objects to create the environments that underpin a smart world.\n \nPNSIOT 2010 provides a premier forum for researchers and engineers alike to present state-of-the-art research and development progresses in all areas related to architecture, design, implementation, application and evaluation of mobile communications and pervasive computing as these technologies are permeating and integrating into our everyday living and working environments.\n \nImportant Dates\n15 March 2010 Submission of manuscripts\n12 April 2010 Notification of acceptance\n10 May 2010 Camera-Ready Version (CRV) due\n12-14 July 2010 Conferences\nSubmission & Publication\nonline submission PNSIOT 2010\n \nInstructions on Manuscripts & Publication\nTopics of particular interest include (but not limited to) the followings.\n \n(1) Pervasive Computing and Communications\n \n- agent technologies for pervasive computing and communications\n- agent-oriented software engineering for pervasive computing\n- ambient intelligence in pervasive environments\n- swarm intelligence models for pervasive computing and communications\n- context-aware computing\n- coordination and interaction models for pervasive computing\n- cross-media for pervasive computing and communications\n- dependable pervasive computing\n- interactions between actors, devices, applications and environments for pervasive computing and communications\n- mobile and ubiquitous computing\n- multimodal interfaces for pervasive computing devices,\n- pervasive context-aware computing\n- pervasive autonomic communications\n- pervasive computing and communication architectures\n- pervasive embedded systems and software\n- pervasive sensing, perception and semantic interpretation\n- pervasive autonomic computing\n- privacy, security, and trust in pervasive computing and communications\n- programming paradigms for pervasive systems\n- self-organization of pervasive multi-agent systems\n- sensor-enabled pervasive environments\n- sensors and RFID in pervasive systems\n- situated communications\n- smart devices, programmable and active networks for pervasive computing\n- ultra-low power and green pervasive computing and communication\n- usability and HCI issues for pervasive computing\n- user and context self-awareness for pervasive computing and communication\n- virtual immersive communications\n- wearable computers\n- wireless ad hoc networks for pervasive computing and communications\n- wireless sensor networks for pervasive computing and communications\n \n(2) Pervasive Networking\n \n- cross-layer design in wireless networks\n- integrated wireline/wireless networks\n- internetworking heterogeneous wireless/wireline networks\n- media and content distribution over wireless networks\n- mobile ad-hoc networks\n- mobile and wireless IP\n- mobile/wireless networks modeling and simulation\n- multi-hop wireless networks\n- network monitoring and accounting in wireless and mobile environment\n- networks convergence and integration\n- performance of end-to-end protocols over wireless networks\n- policy based management in wireless LANs and MANs\n- proxies and middleware for wireless networks\n- routing in multihop, ad hoc and sensor networks\n- topology control in wireless networks\n- traffic and congestion control, QoS, resource management in wireless networks\n- wireless ad hoc networks\n- wireless and mobile network planning\n- wireless broadband mobile access\n- wireless LANs, MANs\n- wireless MAC protocols\n- wireless mesh networks\n- wireless multicasting\n- wireless networks managements\n- wireless protocols and architectures\n- wireless sensor networks\n- wireless WANs: 2G/3G/4G\n- wireless-wireline convergence\n \n(3) Internet of Things\n \n- electronic product code (EPC)\n- EPC information services\n- future internet\n- global ad hoc\n- internet of services\n- nanotechnology\n- object naming service (ONS)\n- RFID and beyond\n- security and privacy in the Internet of Things\n- sensor webs\n- smart devices, smart objects\n- ubiquitous network societies\n- web 2.0\n- web of things\n \n(4) Pervasive Infrastructures and Services\n \n- agent-based service-oriented architectures for pervasive computing and communications\n- agent-based web service discovery and composition systems\n- autonomy-oriented architectures for pervasive computing and communications\n- data mining in pervasive environments\n- knowledge management for pervasive computing\n- middleware services for pervasive computing and communications\n- mobility management\n- multi-agent architectures for pervasive computing and communications\n- peer-to-peer services for pervasive computing and communications\n- pervasive grid computing\n- pervasive middleware\n- pervasive P2P and scalable computing\n- pervasive service discovery protocols and platforms (OSGi, Jini, UPnP, zeroconf, etc.)\n- pervasive service and semantic web\n- pervasive service dissemination and discovery protocols\n- runtime support for intelligent, adaptive agents\n- security services for applications in pervasive environments\n- software infrastructures and frameworks for pervasive computing\n- spontaneous and ad hoc service emergence\n- tools, infrastructures, architectures and techniques for designing, implementing & deploying pervasive computing systems\n \n(5) Pervasive Applications\n \n- ambient intelligent environments\n- common application platform for pervasive computing\n- health and wellness measurement and monitoring by ambient intelligence technologies\n- healthcare information storage, transmission, processing, and monitoring by mobile and wireless sensor networks\n- human-centered pervasive and ubiquitous computing technology for healthcare and wellness\n- novel applications of pervasive computing technologies\n- pervasive assistive environments\n- pervasive automotive and traffic control and monitoring\n- pervasive collaboration and teamwork\n- pervasive healthcare management\n- pervasive healthcare, ubiquitous healthcare\n- positioning and tracking technologies\n- security and privacy in pervasive healthcare\n- smart homes (OGSi, HAVi, DLNA, homePNA, homeRF)\n- pervasive transport\n- socio-technical issues and implications of pervasive computing\n- ubiquitous learning\n \nProgram Chairs\n \nProfessor Qianbin Chen\nKey Lab of Mobile Communications Technology\nChongqing University of Posts and Telecommunications\nChongqing 400065, China\nE-mail\n \nDr. J. Martin Serrano-Orozco\nWaterford Institute of Technology\nTelecommunication Software and Systems Group\nWest Campus, Carriganore \nCo. Waterford, Ireland\nE-mail\n \nProfessor Huaglory Tianfield\nSchool of Engineering and Computing\nGlasgow Caledonian University\nCowcaddens Road\nGlasgow, G4 0BA, United Kingdom\nE-mail (:, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, A, CALL, FOR, PAPERS, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, :, \n, The, 1st, International, Conference, on, Pervasive, Networked, Services, and, Internet, of, Things, \n, 12, -, 14th, July, 2010, \n, Chongqing, ,, PRC, \n\n\n, Background, \n\n, Pervasive, computing, is, emerging, as, the, next, paradigm, for, distributed, and, mobile, computing, through, building, systems, of, communicating, miniaturized, devices, ,, sensors, and, actuators, in, which, ambient, ,, personalized, trustworthy, services, built, ...) Chongqing [:::::::::::: A CALL FOR PAPERS ::::::::::::::::::::::::::, The 1st International Conference on Pervasive Networked Services and Internet of Things, 12-14th July 2010, Chongqing, PRC, Background, Pervasive computing is emerging as the next paradigm for distributed and mobile computing through building systems of communicating miniaturized devices, sensors and actuators in which ambient, personalized trustworthy services built out of pervasive infrastructure and information are seamlessly available anywhere, anytime, and in all forms, By embedding ambient intelligence in everyday objects, our workplaces, our homes and even ourselves, pervasive computing and communications will enable a new breed of applications and systems which are composed of massive smart objects to create the environments that underpin a smart world., , PNSIOT 2010 provides a premier forum for researchers and engineers alike to present state-of-the-art research and development progresses in all areas related to architecture, design, implementation, application and evaluation of mobile communications and pervasive computing as these technologies are permeating and integrating into our everyday living and working environments., , Important Dates, 15 March 2010 Submission of manuscripts, 12 April 2010 Notification of acceptance, 10 May 2010 Camera-Ready Version (CRV) due, 12-14 July 2010 Conferences, Submission & Publication, online submission PNSIOT 2010, , Instructions on Manuscripts & Publication, Topics of particular interest include (but not limited to) the followings., , (1) Pervasive Computing and Communications, , - agent technologies for pervasive computing and communications, - agent-oriented software engineering for pervasive computing, - ambient intelligence in pervasive environments, - swarm intelligence models for pervasive computing and communications, - context-aware computing, - coordination and interaction models for pervasive computing, - cross-media for pervasive computing and communications, - dependable pervasive computing, - interactions between actors, devices, applications and environments for pervasive computing and communications, - mobile and ubiquitous computing, - multimodal interfaces for pervasive computing devices,, - pervasive context-aware computing, - pervasive autonomic communications, - pervasive computing and communication architectures, - pervasive embedded systems and software, - pervasive sensing, perception and semantic interpretation, - pervasive autonomic computing, - privacy, security, and trust in pervasive computing and communications, - programming paradigms for pervasive systems, - self-organization of pervasive multi-agent systems, - sensor-enabled pervasive environments, - sensors and RFID in pervasive systems, - situated communications, - smart devices, programmable and active networks for pervasive computing, - ultra-low power and green pervasive computing and communication, - usability and HCI issues for pervasive computing, - user and context self-awareness for pervasive computing and communication, - virtual immersive communications, - wearable computers, - wireless ad hoc networks for pervasive computing and communications, - wireless sensor networks for pervasive computing and communications, , (2) Pervasive Networking, , - cross-layer design in wireless networks, - integrated wireline/wireless networks, - internetworking heterogeneous wireless/wireline networks, - media and content distribution over wireless networks, - mobile ad-hoc networks, - mobile and wireless IP, - mobile/wireless networks modeling and simulation, - multi-hop wireless networks, - network monitoring and accounting in wireless and mobile environment, - networks convergence and integration, - performance of end-to-end protocols over wireless networks, - policy based management in wireless LANs and MANs, - proxies and middleware for wireless networks, - routing in multihop, ad hoc and sensor networks, - topology control in wireless networks, - traffic and congestion control, QoS, resource management in wireless networks, - wireless ad hoc networks, - wireless and mobile network planning, - wireless broadband mobile access, - wireless LANs, MANs, - wireless MAC protocols, - wireless mesh networks, - wireless multicasting, - wireless networks managements, - wireless protocols and architectures, - wireless sensor networks, - wireless WANs: 2G/3G/4G, - wireless-wireline convergence, , (3) Internet of Things, , - electronic product code (EPC), - EPC information services, - future internet, - global ad hoc, - internet of services, - nanotechnology, - object naming service (ONS), - RFID and beyond, - security and privacy in the Internet of Things, - sensor webs, - smart devices, smart objects, - ubiquitous network societies, ...] The 1st International Conference on Pervasive Networked Services and Internet of Things {'12-14th July 2010': '12-14th july 2010', '15 March 2010': '15 march 2010 submission of manuscripts', '12 April 2010': '12 april 2010 notification of acceptance', '10 May 2010': '10 may 2010 camera-ready version (crv) due', '12-14 July 2010': '12-14 july 2010 conferences', '400065': 'chongqing 400065, china'}
13 22nd Annual Psychology of Programming Interest Group Madrid, Spain Call for Papers #\nPPIG2010\n22nd Annual Psychology of Programming Interest Group\n\nConference dates: 19 -21 September 2010\n\nAll dates are tentative\n\n * Abstract submission: 29th March 2010\n * Deadline for paper submission: 12th April 2010\n * Notification to authors: 17th May 2010\n * Camera ready copies due: 1st June 2010 \n\n * Deadline for doctoral consortium submission: 31st July 2010 \n\nThe Psychology of Programming Interest Group (PPIG) invites software engineers and researchers to submit papers for its 22nd meeting, to be held at the University Carlos III of Madrid, on Sept 19th-21st, and co-located with VL/HCC 2010.\n\nThe annual PPIG (Psychology of Programming Interest Group) workshop is a forum in which researchers concerned with psychological aspects of software development can present and discuss recent results, findings and developments. The workshop is open to the breadth of concerns related to psychological aspects of programming and software engineering, and the broad spectrum of research approaches currently found in the field. It is a place to come and meet fellow researchers, participate in lively discussion and learn about the latest work in this small, but active research community.\n\nExperienced researchers and practitioners, as well as doctoral students, are equally invited to submit.\n\nIf you have any queries as to whether your topic falls within the remit of PPIG, then please do not hesitate to contact the Programme Chair.\n\nThemes can include, but are not limited to:\n\n * Empirical studies of programming\n * Programming education and skills acquisition\n * Human centered design and evaluation of programming languages, tools and infrastructure\n * Programming and human cognition\n * Human Computer Interaction issues in programming\n * Team/cooperative work in programming\n * End user programming\n * Distributed programming, globalisation, work in large teams\n * Free/libre open source software development\n * Software engineering methods, planning, estimation, agility etc.\n * Gender, age, culture and programming\n * New paradigms in programming\n * Code quality, readability and re-use\n * Mistakes, bugs, and error handling\n * Working with notation\n * Specialist and domain centered programming tools and languages \n\nOther approaches and insights are welcome.\nSubmission\n\nSubmissions should be 15 pages or less (short papers and work in progress reports are welcome). To format your paper, please use the PPIG Word Template or the LaTeX template. As in previous years, the programme committee will review all submitted papers and, based on their reviews, each accepted paper will be classified as a "Full Technical Paper", or a "Work in Progress Report". All papers accepted for presentation at PPIG 2010 will appear in the workshop proceedings and be archived on the PPIG website.\n\nPapers for the workshop should be submitted to rachel@us.ibm.com. The email title should read "PPIG2010 Paper Submission: [Title of Paper]" and the attached paper should be in .pdf format. We also request that you send us an abstract letting us know of you intent to submit. This helps us organize our review process.\n\nAll dates are tentative\n\n * Abstract submission: 29th March 2010\n * Deadline for paper submission: 12th April 2010\n * Notification to authors: 17th May 2010\n * Camera ready copies due: 1st June 2010 \n\n * Deadline for doctoral consortium submission: 31st July 2010 \n\nDoctoral Consortium\n\nThe Psychology of Programming Interest Group Workshop will again host a doctoral consortium. The event is for research students at all stages of doctoral study. The event will include brief introductions by each of the student participants (on the order of 10 minutes, plus time for questions, depending on the number of students involved) and interactive sessions on the process and nature of Ph.D. research. Experienced researchers, in addition to the organisers, will participate as 'discussants' to add different perspectives and to provide feedback on individual research programs.\n\nSubmission: Applications must provide an overview of your research (max 5 pages) and be submitted by email to rachel@us.ibm.com with the title 'PPIG2010 doctoral consortium submission'. This submission should be in .pdf format.\n\nDeadline: 31st July 2010 (Call, for, Papers, #, \n, PPIG2010, \n, 22nd, Annual, Psychology, of, Programming, Interest, Group, \n\n, Conference, dates, :, 19, -21, September, 2010, \n\n, All, dates, are, tentative, \n\n , *, Abstract, submission, :, 29th, March, 2010, \n , *, Deadline, for, paper, submission, :, 12th, April, 2010, \n , *, Notification, to, authors, :, 17th, May, 2010, \n , *, Camera, ready, copies, due, :, 1st, June, 2010, \n\n , *, Deadline, for, doctoral, consortium, submission, :, 31st, July, 2010, \n\n, The, Psychology, of, Programming, Interest, Group, (, PPIG, ), invites, software, engineers, and, researchers, to, submit, papers, for, its, 22nd, meeting, ,, to, be, ...) Madrid [Call for Papers #, PPIG2010, 22nd Annual Psychology of Programming Interest Group, Conference dates: 19 -21 September 2010, All dates are tentative, * Abstract submission: 29th March 2010, * Deadline for paper submission: 12th April 2010, * Notification to authors: 17th May 2010, * Camera ready copies due: 1st June 2010 , * Deadline for doctoral consortium submission: 31st July 2010 , The Psychology of Programming Interest Group (PPIG) invites software engineers and researchers to submit papers for its 22nd meeting, to be held at the University Carlos III of Madrid, on Sept 19th-21st, and co-located with VL/HCC 2010., The annual PPIG (Psychology of Programming Interest Group) workshop is a forum in which researchers concerned with psychological aspects of software development can present and discuss recent results, findings and developments, The workshop is open to the breadth of concerns related to psychological aspects of programming and software engineering, and the broad spectrum of research approaches currently found in the field, It is a place to come and meet fellow researchers, participate in lively discussion and learn about the latest work in this small, but active research community., Experienced researchers and practitioners, as well as doctoral students, are equally invited to submit., If you have any queries as to whether your topic falls within the remit of PPIG, then please do not hesitate to contact the Programme Chair., Themes can include, but are not limited to:, * Empirical studies of programming, * Programming education and skills acquisition, * Human centered design and evaluation of programming languages, tools and infrastructure, * Programming and human cognition, * Human Computer Interaction issues in programming, * Team/cooperative work in programming, * End user programming, * Distributed programming, globalisation, work in large teams, * Free/libre open source software development, * Software engineering methods, planning, estimation, agility etc., * Gender, age, culture and programming, * New paradigms in programming, * Code quality, readability and re-use, * Mistakes, bugs, and error handling, * Working with notation, * Specialist and domain centered programming tools and languages , Other approaches and insights are welcome., Submission, Submissions should be 15 pages or less (short papers and work in progress reports are welcome), To format your paper, please use the PPIG Word Template or the LaTeX template, As in previous years, the programme committee will review all submitted papers and, based on their reviews, each accepted paper will be classified as a "Full Technical Paper", or a "Work in Progress Report", All papers accepted for presentation at PPIG 2010 will appear in the workshop proceedings and be archived on the PPIG website., Papers for the workshop should be submitted to rachel@us.ibm.com, The email title should read "PPIG2010 Paper Submission: [Title of Paper]" and the attached paper should be in .pdf format, We also request that you send us an abstract letting us know of you intent to submit, This helps us organize our review process., All dates are tentative, * Abstract submission: 29th March 2010, * Deadline for paper submission: 12th April 2010, * Notification to authors: 17th May 2010, * Camera ready copies due: 1st June 2010 , * Deadline for doctoral consortium submission: 31st July 2010 , Doctoral Consortium, The Psychology of Programming Interest Group Workshop will again host a doctoral consortium, The event is for research students at all stages of doctoral study, The event will include brief introductions by each of the student participants (on the order of 10 minutes, plus time for questions, depending on the number of students involved) and interactive sessions on the process and nature of Ph.D, research, Experienced researchers, in addition to the organisers, will participate as 'discussants' to add different perspectives and to provide feedback on individual research programs., Submission: Applications must provide an overview of your research (max 5 pages) and be submitted by email to rachel@us.ibm.com with the title 'PPIG2010 doctoral consortium submission', This submission should be in .pdf format., Deadline: 31st July 2010] 22nd Annual Psychology of Programming Interest Group {'19 -21 September 2010': 'conference dates: 19 -21 september 2010', '29th March 2010': ' * abstract submission: 29th march 2010', '12th April 2010': ' * deadline for paper submission: 12th april 2010', '17th May 2010': ' * notification to authors: 17th may 2010', '1st June 2010': ' * camera ready copies due: 1st june 2010 ', '31st July 2010': 'deadline: 31st july 2010', 'Sept 19th-21st': 'the psychology of programming interest group (ppig) invites software engineers and researchers to submit papers for its 22nd meeting, to be held at the university carlos iii of madrid, on sept 19th-21st, and co-located with vl/hcc 2010.'}
14 Second International Workshop on Collaborative Agents -- REsearch and development (CARE) Toronto, Canada Apologies for multiple postings.\n\n============================================================\nSecond INTERNATIONAL WORKSHOP on \nCollaborative Agents -- REsearch and Development (CARE) 2010\n31st August 2010, York University, Toronto, Canada\n\nAbstract submission: April 14, 2010\nFull paper submission: April 16, 2010\n\nhttp://www.csse.monash.edu.au/~xtg/CARE2010/\n============================================================\n\nThe workshop is held in conjunction with the International Conference on Intelligent Agent Technology (IAT).\nhttp://www.yorku.ca/wiiat10/\n\nSummary\n=======\n\nCollaboration is required when multiple agents achieve complex goals that are difficult or impossible to attain for an individual agent. This collaboration takes place under conditions of incomplete information, uncertainty, and bounded rationality, much of which has been previously studied in economics and artificial intelligence. However, many real world domains are characterised by even greater complexity, including the possibility of unreliable and non-complying collaborators, complex market and incentive frameworks, and complex transaction costs and organisational structures. This workshop's thematic focus is on collaborative and autonomous agents that plan, negotiate, coordinate, and act under this complexity.\n \nThis workshop aims to foster discussions on computational models of collaboration in distributed systems, addressing a range of theoretical and practical issues. We seek contributions of members in research and industry that use the agent paradigm to approach their problems.\n \nSome issues of interest of this workshop are:\no How to enable agents to form and follow joint agreements and contracts in complex organisational and market driven domains.\no How to develop a comprehensive contractual formation/maintenance framework applicable to many application domains.\no How to build comprehensive customer lifecycle management systems for customers, including telecommunication consumers, students and patients.\no How to deploy lifecycle management systems in real world applications, such as healthcare, telecommunication, and smart campuses.\no How to design markets that are adequate for agents to act with incomplete and uncertain information of the behaviour of collaborating agents. \no How to build MAS that work efficiently in partially regulated markets (where governance policy or partnership agreements govern part of the market).\no What are the implications of partial regulation on the management of contractual relationships and service delivery.\no How organisational structures influence the negotiation of agents and the distribution/execution of tasks.\no How to cope with collaborators that exhibit unreliable and non-conformant behaviour, eg where agreements are made but are not always conformed with.\no How can interventions and incentive structures assist in managing contractual relationships and service delivery.\no How to assign transaction costs to actions in planning, assignment, and execution in organisational structures. \no How can transaction costs influence the social outcome of the system which is further influenced by the organisational context under which the collaboration takes place. \no Can lessons learnt in game theoretic computation inform collaborative agent settings.\no What role does learning and adaptivity play in building organisational MAS.\n\nThe one day workshop will feature a mixture of invited talks, discussions and submitted contributions describing current work or work in progress in collaborative agent research and technology. The workshop environment fosters open discussions among all participants, particularly encouraging students to discuss their research topics and seek feedback from senior agent researchers.\n\n\nContact\n=======\n\nCARE organisers\n\nchristian.guttmann@gmail.com\ndignum@cs.uu.nl \n\n\nImportant Dates\n===============\n\nAbstract submission: April 14, 2010\nFull paper submission: April 16, 2010\n Notification: May 28, 2010\nCamera ready: June 7, 2010\n\n\nTopics of Interest include (but are not limited to):\n====================================================\n\nRESEARCH\n* Collaboration frameworks\n* Models of teamwork and joint action\n* Organisation/Institutes/Norms\n* Auctioning/Negotiation\n* Task/Resource allocation\n* Behaviour modelling/monitoring\n* Adherence/Intervention mechanisms\n* Incentive frameworks\n* Intervention mechanisms\n* Agreement technology\n* Contract networks/formation\n* Cloud computing\n\nAPPLICATION AREAS\n* Collaborative care planning/management \n* Disaster planning/management\n* Traffic planning/management\n* Transport/Logistics\n* Applications in primary and preventative healthcare \n* Chronic disease planning/management\n* Epidemiological agent models\n* Unmanned air/land vehicles\n* Robotic soccer/Robotic rescues\n* Weather forecast\n* Artificial and natural immune systems\n* Social networks (e.g., LinkedIn, Facebook,...)\n* Smart grid network (e.g., electricity/gas metering)\n\nSubmission and Publication\n==========================\n\nSubmission is to be done electronically at Cyberchair at: http://wi-consortium.org/cyberchair/wiiat10/scripts/ws_submit.php. \nCARE 2010 seeks 4-page submissions formatted according to IEEE specification. \n\nStyle Files for Paper Submission\nIEEE Computer Society Proceedings Manuscript Formatting Guidelines:\nDOC: ftp://pubftp.computer.org/press/outgoing/proceedings/instruct8.5x11.doc \nPDF:ftp://pubftp.computer.org/press/outgoing/proceedings/instruct8.5x11.pdf \nPS: ftp://pubftp.computer.org/press/outgoing/proceedings/instruct.ps \nLaTex Formatting Macros:\nftp://pubftp.computer.org/Press/Outgoing/proceedings/IEEE_CS_Latex8.5x11x2.zip\n\nSubmissions will be peer-reviewed by two or three reviewers per paper. Selection criteria will include relevance, significance, impact, originality, technical soundness, quality of presentation. Some preference may also be given to papers which address emergent trends or important common themes, or which enhance balance of workshop topics.\n\n\nWorkshop Officials\n==================\n\nGENERAL CHAIR\nChristian Guttmann (Monash University, Australia)\nFrank Dignum (University Utrecht, Netherlands)\n\nPROGRAM COMMITTEE\nWei Chen (Intelligent Automation, Inc., United States of America)\nPhilippe Pasquier (Simon Fraser University, Canada) \nMichael Luck (King's College London, United Kingdom)\nLawrence Cavedon (NICTA and RMIT University, Australia)\nSamin Karim (Accenture, Australia)\nCees Witteveen (Delft University of Technology, Netherlands)\t\nFranziska
