27 IEEE 2010 CBSA: Conference for Cloud-based Services and Applications Miami Florida, USA CALL FOR PAPERS\n\nIEEE 2010 CBSA: Conference for Cloud-based Services and Applications\nMiami, Florida, USA\nConference date: July 5 - 10, 2010\n\nhttp://acet.rdg.ac.uk/events/index.php\n\nDescription\n\nCloud computing is increasingly being used for what was known as "on-demand" and "utility computing". The services provided, the APIs and the applications that can be hosted by these Cloud providers have superseded the use of the grid, and are increasingly becoming popular with users. The Cloud is a paradigm shift, where details are abstracted from the users; they no longer need expert knowledge about using the various technologies and running their applications on service infrastructure. Cloud computing provides a consumption and delivery model for IT services based on Internet, and it typically involves the provision of dynamically scalable and virtualized services.\n\nThere services that are provided by various Cloud providers, which include commercial entities, such as Amazon and Google, as well as those that are open-source systems, such as provided by Open Cirrus and Eucalyptus.\n\nIn this workshop we will examine and explore the services, interfaces and types of applications that can be executed on Cloud systems. In addition, we are interested in the interfaces used to access the underlying services, the processes of using virtualization, the range and scope of applications that can be executed, the security used by these services, and aspects such a service level agreements and quality of service provided. In addition, we are keen to know about the services that are used, and whether these are appropriate for various types of applications, such as sophisticated workflows and HPC.\n\nSubmission Dates\n\n * April 1st, 2010, paper submission,\n * April 15th, 2010, notification,\n * April 30th, 2010, camera-ready version due.\n\nList of topics\n\n * Security Policies and Mechanisms,\n * Possession and ownership of data,\n * Scheduling on Clouds,\n * Cloud benchmarks,\n * Cloud-based services and protocols,\n * Cloud Interoperability,\n * Cloud Frameworks and Services,\n * Storage and file systems,\n * Cloud scalability and performance,\n * Fault-tolerance,\n * Application development and debugging tools,\n * Business models and economics of cloud services,\n * Vituralization of hardware and software resources,\n * Performance monitoring and prediction of cloud performance,\n * Capacity planning and resource allocation,\n * Service Level Agreements and Quality of Services,\n * Cloud architectures,\n * Use of various Applications on Cloud-based systems. (CALL, FOR, PAPERS, \n\n, IEEE, 2010, CBSA, :, Conference, for, Cloud, -, based, Services, and, Applications, \n, Miami, ,, Florida, ,, USA, \n, Conference, date, :, July, 5, -, 10, ,, 2010, \n\n, http://acet.rdg.ac.uk, /, events, /, index.php, \n\n, Description, \n\n, Cloud, computing, is, increasingly, being, used, for, what, was, known, as, ", on, -, demand, ", and, ", utility, computing, ", ., The, services, provided, ,, the, APIs, and, the, applications, that, can, be, hosted, by, these, Cloud, providers, have, superseded, the, use, of, the, grid, ,, and, are, increasingly, becoming, popular, with, users, ., The, Cloud, is, a, ...) Florida [CALL FOR PAPERS, IEEE 2010 CBSA: Conference for Cloud-based Services and Applications, Miami, Florida, USA, Conference date: July 5 - 10, 2010, http://acet.rdg.ac.uk/events/index.php, Description, Cloud computing is increasingly being used for what was known as "on-demand" and "utility computing", The services provided, the APIs and the applications that can be hosted by these Cloud providers have superseded the use of the grid, and are increasingly becoming popular with users, The Cloud is a paradigm shift, where details are abstracted from the users; they no longer need expert knowledge about using the various technologies and running their applications on service infrastructure, Cloud computing provides a consumption and delivery model for IT services based on Internet, and it typically involves the provision of dynamically scalable and virtualized services., There services that are provided by various Cloud providers, which include commercial entities, such as Amazon and Google, as well as those that are open-source systems, such as provided by Open Cirrus and Eucalyptus., In this workshop we will examine and explore the services, interfaces and types of applications that can be executed on Cloud systems, In addition, we are interested in the interfaces used to access the underlying services, the processes of using virtualization, the range and scope of applications that can be executed, the security used by these services, and aspects such a service level agreements and quality of service provided, In addition, we are keen to know about the services that are used, and whether these are appropriate for various types of applications, such as sophisticated workflows and HPC., Submission Dates, * April 1st, 2010, paper submission,, * April 15th, 2010, notification,, * April 30th, 2010, camera-ready version due., List of topics, * Security Policies and Mechanisms,, * Possession and ownership of data,, * Scheduling on Clouds,, * Cloud benchmarks,, * Cloud-based services and protocols,, * Cloud Interoperability,, * Cloud Frameworks and Services,, * Storage and file systems,, * Cloud scalability and performance,, * Fault-tolerance,, * Application development and debugging tools,, * Business models and economics of cloud services,, * Vituralization of hardware and software resources,, * Performance monitoring and prediction of cloud performance,, * Capacity planning and resource allocation,, * Service Level Agreements and Quality of Services,, * Cloud architectures,, * Use of various Applications on Cloud-based systems.] IEEE 2010 CBSA: Conference for Cloud-based Services and Applications {'July 5 - 10, 2010': 'conference date: july 5 - 10, 2010', 'April 1st, 2010': ' * april 1st, 2010, paper submission,', 'April 15th, 2010': ' * april 15th, 2010, notification,', 'April 30th, 2010': ' * april 30th, 2010, camera-ready version due.'}
28 ACL 2010 workshop on NLP and Linguistics: Finding the Common Ground Uppsala, Sweden Call for Papers\nACL 2010 workshop on NLP and Linguistics: Finding the Common Ground\n Uppsala, Sweden\n July 16, 2010\n\n Workshop website:\n http://faculty.washington.edu/fxia/nlpling2010/\n\n Submission website:\n https://www.softconf.com/acl2010/NLPLing/\n\n\n1. Workshop Description\n \nThis workshop aims at examining the relationship between linguistics and\nNLP and studying\n(1) the new methods in incorporating linguistic knowledge into statistical\n systems to advance the state of the art of NLP, and\n(2) the feasibility of using NLP techniques to acquire linguistic knowledge\n for a large number of languages and to assist linguistic studies.\n\n Since early 1990s, with the advancement of machine learning methods and the\navailability of data resources such as treebanks and parallel corpora,\ndata-driven approaches to NLP have made significant progress. The success\nof such data-driven approaches has cast doubt on the relevance of\nlinguistics to NLP. Conversely, NLP techniques are rarely used to help\nlinguistics studies. We believe that there is room to expand the\ninvolvement of linguistics in NLP, and likewise, NLP in linguistics, and\nbelieve that the cross-pollination of ideas between the disciplines can\ngreatly benefit both fields.\n\n One common approach to take advantage of linguistic knowledge is to train\na statistical system on linguistically annotated data such as treebanks.\nAnother approach is to represent linguistic knowledge as rules in a\nrule-based approach. This workshop is interested in research that goes\nBEYOND these common approaches and explores new methods in incorporating\nlinguistic knowledge into statistical systems or using statistical systems\nfor linguistic knowledge discovery.\n\n The workshop will consist of one invited talk, 2-3 panels, group discussion,\nand paper/poster sessions.\n\n\n2. Topics of Interest\n \n The workshop is interested in research that explores new methods in\nincorporating linguistic knowledge into statistical systems or using\nstatistical systems for linguistic knowledge discovery.\nThese include, but are not limited to, the following themes:\n\n [T1] Research that shows awareness of particular linguistic phenomena\n and its effects on statistical systems.\n\n For instance, being aware of syntactic phenomena such as scrambling,\n cross-serial dependencies and long-distance movement is very relevant\n to parsing (e.g., earlier work on using different grammar formalisms\n such as LTAG/CCG/HPSG/LFG to handle these phenomena or more recent\n work on non-projective dependency parsing).\n\n Similarly, being aware of word formation patterns (e.g., reduplication\n in Chinese) or allomorphic variation patterns (e.g., vowel harmony in\n Turkish) could help word segmentation and morphological analysis.\n \n\n [T2] New methods in incorporating linguistic knowledge into\n statistical systems to improve the start of the art.\n (e.g., as rules in a preprocessing step, as linguistic features in\n a statistical system, as filters for pruning a search space, as priors\n in an objective function).\n\n\n [T3] Research that demonstrates the feasibility of creating NLP systems to\n automatically acquire linguistic knowledge for a large number of\n languages.\n\n In order to make generalizations about language universals, linguists\n need to gather information about as many individual languages as\n possible. However, knowledge about most languages is not complete.\n Can we use NLP techniques to acquire knowledge (e.g., basic word\n order, case marking, tense, aspect, word formation rules, etc.) for\n hundreds of languages, which could help in the construction of\n resources such as WALS (http://wals.info) (Haspelmath et al., 2005)?\n\n\n [T4] Research that demonstrates the benefits of using NLP techniques to\n help particular linguistic studies. For instance, given some language\n data, can the categorization of languages into families be automated?\n Can historical interactions between languages be identified\n automatically (e.g., areal effects and borrowings, but beyond just\n lexical borrowings)? Can NLP tools run over corpora\n of different dialects of the same language systematically identify\n differences in the two dialects (e.g., not just word choice\n differences, but also choice and frequency of particular\n constructions)?\n \n\n The systems described in the paper should be properly evaluated and\n compared with the start of the art.\n\n On the submission form, please specify the theme that your paper falls into.\n\n \n\n3. Important dates:\n * Submission deadline: April 5, 2010\n * Notification: May 6, 2010\n * Camera-ready deadline: May 16, 2010\n * Workshop: July 16, 2010\n\n\n\n4. Submission Information\n\n The papers should report original and unpublished research on topics of\ninterest for the workshop. Accepted papers are expected to be presented\nat the workshop, and will be published in the workshop proceedings. They\nshould emphasize obtained results rather than intended work, and should\nindicate clearly the state of completion of the reported results.\n\n A paper accepted for presentation at the workshop must not be presented or\nhave been presented at any other meeting with publicly available proceedings.\n\n\n4.1 Submission Format: All submissions must be electronic in PDF and must be\n formatted using the ACL 2010 style files, which are available at\n http://www.acl2010.org/authors.html\n\n4.2 Maximum Length: The maximum length of a submitted paper is\n eight (8) pages of content, excluding references. One additional\n page is allowed for the References section. Thus, your PDF file\n is limited to eight (8) pages of content and nine (9) pages in total.\n\n\n4.3 Anonymous Review: Reviewing of papers will be double-blind. Therefore,\n the paper must not include the authors' names and affiliations.\n Furthermore, self-references that reveal the author's identity, e.g.,\n "We previously showed (Smith, 1991) ...", must be avoided. Instead, use\n citations such as "Smith (1991) previously showed ...". Papers that do\n not conform to these requirements will be rejected without review.\n\n\n4.4 Double Submitting: Papers that have been or will be submitted to other\n meetings or publications must provide this information on the START\n online submission page. If NLPLing 2010 accepts a paper, authors must\n notify the program chairs *immediately* indicating which meeting they\n choose for presentation of their work. NLPLing 2010 cannot accept for\n publication or presentation work that will be (or has been) published\n elsewhere.\n\n\n4.5 Submission site: Authors must submit papers online at\n https://www.softconf.com/acl2010/NLPLing/\n\n4.6 The submission deadline is April 5, 2010 23:59 PST. Papers\n submitted after the deadline will not be reviewed.\n\n\n5. ACL mentoring service:\n\nACL is providing a mentoring (coaching) service for authors from regions of the world where English is less emphasized as a language of scientific exchange. Many authors from these regions, although able to read the scientific literature in English, have little or no experience in writing papers in English for conferences such as the ACL meetings. The service will be arranged as follows. A set of potential mentors will be identified by Mentoring Service Chairs BjÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¶rn GambÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¤ck (SICS, Sweden and NTNU, Norway) and Diana McCarthy (Lexical Computing Ltd., UK), who will organize this service for ACL 2010. If you would like to take advantage of the service for a submission to this workshop, please upload your paper in PDF format using the paper submission software for the mentoring service available at:\n\n\nhttps://www.softconf.com/acl2010/acl2010mentor/\n\nThe deadline for the mentoring service is six weeks before the workshop submission deadline. An appropriate mentor will be assigned to your paper and the mentor will get back to you no later than two weeks before the submission deadline.\n\nPlease note that this service is for the benefit of the authors as described above. It is not a general mentoring service for authors to improve the technical content of their papers.\n\nQuestions about the mentoring service should be referred to mentoring@acl2010.org.\n\n\n\n6. Workshop Chairs\n * Lori Levin, CMU, USA\n * William Lewis, Microsoft Research, USA\n * Fei Xia, Univ. of Washington, USA\n\n\n\n7. Program committee:\n\n * Anthony Aristar, LinguistList, USA\n * Jason Baldridge, University of Texas at Austin, USA\n * Timothy Baldwin, University of Melbourne, Australia\n * Dorothee Beermann, NTNU, Norway\n * Emily M. Bender, University of Washington, USA\n * Steven Bird, University of Melbourne, Australia\n * Chris Brew, Ohio State University, USA\n * Michael Collins, MIT, USA\n * Michael Cysouw, Max Planck Inst. for Evolutionary Anthropology, Germany,\n * Hal Daume III, Univ of Utah, USA\n * Markus Dickinson, University of Indiana, USA\n * Alexis Dimitriadis, Utrecht Institute of Linguistics OTS,\n The Netherlands\n * Helen Aristar Dry, LinguistList\n * Jason Eisner, JHU, USA\n * Chu-Ren Huang, \n The Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ., Hong Kong, China,\n * Julia Hockenmaier, UIUC, USA\n * Mark Johnson, Macquarie University, Australia\n * Kevin Knight, ISI, USA\n * Mark Liberman, Univ of Pennsylvania, USA\n * Dekang Lin, Google, USA\n * Paola Merlo, University of Geneva, Switzerland\n * Kathy McKeown, Columbia Univ, USA\n * Martha Palmer, University of Colorado, USA\n * Dragomir Radev, University of Michigan, USA\n * Owen Rambow, Columbia Univ., USA\n * Dipti Misra Sharma, IIIT, India\n * Richard Sproat, Oregon Health & Science University, USA\n * Mark Steedman, Edinburgh, UK\n * Michael White, Ohio State University, USA\n * Richard Wicentowski, Swarthmore College, USA,\n * Peter Wittenburg, Max Planck Inst. for Psycholinguistics,\n The Netherlands\n * Andreas Witt, Institut fÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¼r Deutsche Sprache, Mannheim, Germany,\n * Nianwen Xue, Brandeis University, USA\n\n\n8. Contact info\n\n If you have any questions about the workshop, please contact us at\nnlpling2010@uw.edu. (Call, for, Papers, \n, ACL, 2010, workshop, on, , NLP, and, Linguistics, :, Finding, the, Common, Ground, \n , Uppsala, ,, Sweden, \n , July, 16, ,, 2010, \n\n , Workshop, website, :, \n , http://faculty.washington.edu/fxia/nlpling2010/, \n\n , Submission, website, :, \n , https://www.softconf.com/acl2010/NLPLing/, \n\n\n, 1, ., Workshop, Description, \n \n, This, workshop, aims, at, examining, the, relationship, between, linguistics, and, \n, NLP, and, studying, \n, (, 1, ), the, new, methods, in, incorporating, linguistic, knowledge, into, statistical, \n , systems, to, advance, the, state, of, the, art, of, NLP, ,, and, \n, (, 2, ), the, feasibility, of, using, NLP, techniques, to, acquire, linguistic, knowledge, \n , for, ...) Sweden [Call for Papers, ACL 2010 workshop on NLP and Linguistics: Finding the Common Ground, Uppsala, Sweden, July 16, 2010, Workshop website:, http://faculty.washington.edu/fxia/nlpling2010/, Submission website:, https://www.softconf.com/acl2010/NLPLing/, 1, Workshop Description, , This workshop aims at examining the relationship between linguistics and, NLP and studying, (1) the new methods in incorporating linguistic knowledge into statistical, systems to advance the state of the art of NLP, and, (2) the feasibility of using NLP techniques to acquire linguistic knowledge, for a large number of languages and to assist linguistic studies., Since early 1990s, with the advancement of machine learning methods and the, availability of data resources such as treebanks and parallel corpora,, data-driven approaches to NLP have made significant progress, The success, of such data-driven approaches has cast doubt on the relevance of, linguistics to NLP, Conversely, NLP techniques are rarely used to help, linguistics studies, We believe that there is room to expand the, involvement of linguistics in NLP, and likewise, NLP in linguistics, and, believe that the cross-pollination of ideas between the disciplines can, greatly benefit both fields., One common approach to take advantage of linguistic knowledge is to train, a statistical system on linguistically annotated data such as treebanks., Another approach is to represent linguistic knowledge as rules in a, rule-based approach, This workshop is interested in research that goes, BEYOND these common approaches and explores new methods in incorporating, linguistic knowledge into statistical systems or using statistical systems, for linguistic knowledge discovery., The workshop will consist of one invited talk, 2-3 panels, group discussion,, and paper/poster sessions., 2, Topics of Interest, , The workshop is interested in research that explores new methods in, incorporating linguistic knowledge into statistical systems or using, statistical systems for linguistic knowledge discovery., These include, but are not limited to, the following themes:, [T1] Research that shows awareness of particular linguistic phenomena, and its effects on statistical systems., For instance, being aware of syntactic phenomena such as scrambling,, cross-serial dependencies and long-distance movement is very relevant, to parsing (e.g., earlier work on using different grammar formalisms, such as LTAG/CCG/HPSG/LFG to handle these phenomena or more recent, work on non-projective dependency parsing)., Similarly, being aware of word formation patterns (e.g., reduplication, in Chinese) or allomorphic variation patterns (e.g., vowel harmony in, Turkish) could help word segmentation and morphological analysis., , [T2] New methods in incorporating linguistic knowledge into, statistical systems to improve the start of the art., (e.g., as rules in a preprocessing step, as linguistic features in, a statistical system, as filters for pruning a search space, as priors, in an objective function)., [T3] Research that demonstrates the feasibility of creating NLP systems to, automatically acquire linguistic knowledge for a large number of, languages., In order to make generalizations about language universals, linguists, need to gather information about as many individual languages as, possible, However, knowledge about most languages is not complete., Can we use NLP techniques to acquire knowledge (e.g., basic word, order, case marking, tense, aspect, word formation rules, etc.) for, hundreds of languages, which could help in the construction of, resources such as WALS (http://wals.info) (Haspelmath et al., 2005)?, [T4] Research that demonstrates the benefits of using NLP techniques to, help particular linguistic studies, For instance, given some language, data, can the categorization of languages into families be automated?, Can historical interactions between languages be identified, automatically (e.g., areal effects and borrowings, but beyond just, lexical borrowings)? Can NLP tools run over corpora, of different dialects of the same language systematically identify, differences in the two dialects (e.g., not just word choice, differences, but also choice and frequency of particular, constructions)?, , The systems described in the paper should be properly evaluated and, compared with the start of the art., On the submission form, please specify the theme that your paper falls into., , 3, Important dates:, * Submission deadline: April 5, 2010, * Notification: May 6, 2010, * Camera-ready deadline: May 16, 2010, * Workshop: July 16, 2010, 4, Submission Information, The papers should report original and unpublished research on topics of, interest for the workshop, Accepted papers are expected to be presented, ...] ACL 2010 workshop on NLP and Linguistics: Finding the Common Ground {'July 16, 2010': ' * workshop: july 16, 2010', 'April 5, 2010': '4.6 the submission deadline is april 5, 2010 23:59 pst', 'May 6, 2010': ' * notification: may 6, 2010', 'May 16, 2010': ' * camera-ready deadline: may 16, 2010', 'six weeks': 'the deadline for the mentoring service is six weeks before the workshop submission deadline'}
29 TextGraphs-5: Conference for Graph-based Methods for Natural Language Processing Uppsala, Sweden TextGraphs-5: Conference for Graph-based Methods for Natural Language Processing\n=================================================================\n\nWorkshop at ACL 2010\nAssociation for Computational Linguistics Conference\nUppsala, Sweden - July 16th, 2010\nhttp://www.textgraphs.org/ws10/\n\nDeadline for paper submission: Monday, April 5th, 2010\n\nTextGraphs is at its fifth edition! This shows that two seemingly distinct\ndisciplines,\ngraph theoretic models to computational linguistics, are in fact intimately\nconnected,\nwith a large variety of Natural Language Processing (NLP) applications\nadopting efficient\nand elegant solutions from graph-theoretical framework.\n\nThe TextGraphs workshop series addresses a broad spectrum of research areas\nand\nbrings together specialists working on graph-based models and algorithms for\nnatural\nlanguage processing and computational linguistics, as well as on the\ntheoretical\nfoundations of related graph-based methods. This workshop series is aimed at\nfostering an exchange of ideas by facilitating a discussion about both the\ntechniques\nand the theoretical justification of the empirical results among the NLP\ncommunity\nmembers. Spawning a deeper understanding of the basic theoretical principles\ninvolved,\nsuch interaction is vital to the further progress of graph-based NLP\napplications.\n\n\nSpecial Theme: Graph Methods for Opinion Analysis\n----------------------------------------------------------------\n\nFor the fifth edition of TextGraphs, we propose the special theme: "Graph\nMethods for\nOpinion Analysis". This choice is motivated by two important factors: (1)\nadvanced\nopinion analysis that aims to go beyond polarity recognition necessitates\nthe integration\nof syntactic, semantic and logic structures and (2) previous work in NLP has\nshown that\ngraph methods are very well suited to represent and exploit such structures\nin learning\nsystems.\n\nThe aim is to bring together researchers from graph theory and opinion\nanalysis in\norder to enable cross-fertilization of ideas. The proposed theme will\nencourage\npublication of early results and initiate discussions of issues in this\narea. We hope that\nthis will help to shape future directions for ambitious opinion analysis\nresearch and\nprovide a new, challenging problem motivation for research in graph\nalgorithms.\n\nFinally, as the field of opinion mining advances towards deeper analysis and\nmore\ncomplex systems, graphical approaches may become even more pertinent. For\ninstance,\ngraphs may be employed to capture opinion dynamics over time, or to model\ninteractions between opinion expressions across multiple modalities and, to\nrealize this,\nnew graph-based algorithms and inference methods may need to be developed.\n\n\nSuggested topics\n---------------------\n\nWe invite submissions on the following (but not limited to) general topics\n(including those\nfrom the special theme):\n* Graph methods for sentiment lexicon induction\n* Analysis of blog and web linking structures\n* Graph methods for sentiment/opinion propagation\n* Graph representation of data for opinion analysis\n* Synonym/antonym graphs and their usage to extrapolate semantic orientation\n* Social graphs and opinion analysis\n* Graph-based representations, acquisition and evaluation of lexicon and\nontology\n* Dynamic graph representations for NLP\n* Properties of lexical, semantic, syntactic and phonological graphs\n* Clustering-based algorithms\n* Application of spectral graph theory in NLP\n* Unsupervised and semi-supervised learning models based-on graphs\n* Dynamic graph representations for NLP\n* Comparative analysis of graph-based methods and traditional machine\nlearning\nTechniques for NLP applications\n* Kernel Methods for Graphs, e.g. random walk, tree and sequence kernels\n* Graph methods for NLP tasks, e.g. morpho-syntactic annotation, word sense\ndisambiguation, syntactic/semantic parsing\n* Graph methods for NLP applications, e.g. retrieval, extraction and\nsummarization of\ninformation\n* Semantic inference using graphs, e.g. question answering and text\nentailment\nrecognition\n\n\nImportant Dates\n--------------------\n\n* Deadline for paper submission: Monday, April 5th, 2010\n* Notification of acceptance: Thursday, May 6th, 2010\n* Submission of camera-ready articles: Friday, June 4th, 2010\n* Workshop at ACL 2010: Friday, July 16th, 2010\n\n\nOrganizing Committee\n---------------------------\n\n* Carmen Banea, University of North Texas,\n* Alessandro Moschitti, University of Trento,\n* Swapna Somasundaran, University of Pittsburgh,\n* Fabio Massimo Zanzotto, University of Rome "Tor Vergata"\n\n\nProgram Committee\n-------------------------\n\n* Giuseppe Carenini, University of British Columbia\n* Monojit Choudhury, Microsoft Research, India\n* William Cohen, Carnegie Mellon University\n* Andras Csomai, Google Inc.\n* Michael Gamon, Microsoft Research, Redmond\n* Thomas Gartner, Fraunhofer Institute for Intelligent Analysis and\nInformation Systems\n* Lise Getoor, University of Maryland\n* Andrew Goldberg, University of Wisconsin, Madison\n* Eduard Hovy, Information Sciences Institute\n* Richard Johansson, Trento University\n* Lillian Lee, Cornell University\n* Smaranda Muresan, Rutgers University\n* Fabrizio Sebastiani, Istituto di Scienza e Tecnologia dell'Informazione\n* Veselin Stoyanov, Cornell University\n* Carlo Strapparava, Istituto per la Ricerca Scientifica e Tecnologica\n* Hiroya Takamura, Tokyo Institute of Technology\n* Dragomir R. Radev, University of Michigan\n* Lluis Marquez Villodre, Universidad Politecnica de Catalunya\n* Theresa Wilson, University of Edinburgh\n* Xiaojin Zhu, University of Wisconsin, Madison\n* Michael Strube, EML research\n* Ulf Brefeld, Yahoo! (TextGraphs-5, :, Conference, for, Graph, -, based, Methods, for, Natural, Language, Processing, \n, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, \n\n, Workshop, at, ACL, 2010, \n, Association, for, Computational, Linguistics, Conference, \n, Uppsala, ,, Sweden, -, July, 16th, ,, 2010, \n, http://www.textgraphs.org/ws10/, ...) Uppsala [TextGraphs-5: Conference for Graph-based Methods for Natural Language Processing, =================================================================, Workshop at ACL 2010, Association for Computational Linguistics Conference, Uppsala, Sweden - July 16th, 2010, http://www.textgraphs.org/ws10/, Deadline for paper submission: Monday, April 5th, 2010, TextGraphs is at its fifth edition! This shows that two seemingly distinct, disciplines,, graph theoretic models to computational linguistics, are in fact intimately, connected,, with a large variety of Natural Language Processing (NLP) applications, adopting efficient, and elegant solutions from graph-theoretical framework., The TextGraphs workshop series addresses a broad spectrum of research areas, and, brings together specialists working on graph-based models and algorithms for, natural, language processing and computational linguistics, as well as on the, theoretical, foundations of related graph-based methods, This workshop series is aimed at, fostering an exchange of ideas by facilitating a discussion about both the, techniques, and the theoretical justification of the empirical results among the NLP, community, members, Spawning a deeper understanding of the basic theoretical principles, involved,, such interaction is vital to the further progress of graph-based NLP, applications., Special Theme: Graph Methods for Opinion Analysis, ----------------------------------------------------------------, For the fifth edition of TextGraphs, we propose the special theme: "Graph, Methods for, Opinion Analysis", This choice is motivated by two important factors: (1), advanced, opinion analysis that aims to go beyond polarity recognition necessitates, the integration, of syntactic, semantic and logic structures and (2) previous work in NLP has, shown that, graph methods are very well suited to represent and exploit such structures, in learning, systems., The aim is to bring together researchers from graph theory and opinion, analysis in, order to enable cross-fertilization of ideas, The proposed theme will, encourage, publication of early results and initiate discussions of issues in this, area, We hope that, this will help to shape future directions for ambitious opinion analysis, research and, provide a new, challenging problem motivation for research in graph, algorithms., Finally, as the field of opinion mining advances towards deeper analysis and, more, complex systems, graphical approaches may become even more pertinent, For, instance,, graphs may be employed to capture opinion dynamics over time, or to model, interactions between opinion expressions across multiple modalities and, to, realize this,, new graph-based algorithms and inference methods may need to be developed., Suggested topics, ---------------------, We invite submissions on the following (but not limited to) general topics, (including those, from the special theme):, * Graph methods for sentiment lexicon induction, * Analysis of blog and web linking structures, * Graph methods for sentiment/opinion propagation, * Graph representation of data for opinion analysis, * Synonym/antonym graphs and their usage to extrapolate semantic orientation, * Social graphs and opinion analysis, * Graph-based representations, acquisition and evaluation of lexicon and, ontology, * Dynamic graph representations for NLP, * Properties of lexical, semantic, syntactic and phonological graphs, * Clustering-based algorithms, * Application of spectral graph theory in NLP, * Unsupervised and semi-supervised learning models based-on graphs, * Dynamic graph representations for NLP, * Comparative analysis of graph-based methods and traditional machine, learning, Techniques for NLP applications, * Kernel Methods for Graphs, e.g, random walk, tree and sequence kernels, * Graph methods for NLP tasks, e.g, morpho-syntactic annotation, word sense, disambiguation, syntactic/semantic parsing, * Graph methods for NLP applications, e.g, retrieval, extraction and, summarization of, information, * Semantic inference using graphs, e.g, question answering and text, entailment, ...] TextGraphs-5: Conference for Graph-based Methods for Natural Language Processing {'July 16th, 2010': 'uppsala, sweden - july 16th, 2010', 'Monday, April 5th, 2010': '* deadline for paper submission: monday, april 5th, 2010', 'Thursday': '* notification of acceptance: thursday, may 6th, 2010', 'May 6th, 2010': '* notification of acceptance: thursday, may 6th, 2010', 'Friday, June 4th, 2010': '* submission of camera-ready articles: friday, june 4th, 2010', 'Friday, July 16th, 2010': '* workshop at acl 2010: friday, july 16th, 2010'}
30 Fifth IEEE Workshop On Networking Technologies For Softward Defined Radio (Sdr) Networks Boston, USA Fifth IEEE Workshop On Networking Technologies For Softward Defined Radio (Sdr) Networks\n\nLooking for paper submissions.\n\nMotivated by the skyrocketing demand for radio spectrum, facilitated by regulatory policy movements, and enabled by advances in RF technologies, there has been significant research towards developing networking technologies for white spaces -- the allocated but unutilized and under-utilized radio spectrum. One noticeable example is the recent prototype development and FCC historical rulings on white spaces in the TV bands. This workshop aims at providing a timely venue for discussing the current activities and findings in the field of cognitive radio networks, dynamic spectrum access, interference prevention, coexistence, and regulatory issues. This workshop will focus on recent advances as well as challenging papers. Areas of interest include but are not limited to:\n\n * Spectrum Sensing and Spectrum Management\n * Cognitive Radio Test-Beds and Hardware Prototypes\n * DSA/Cognitive Radio Standardization Activities (e.g. IEEE P1900, IEEE 802.22)\n * Accreditation, Trust, & Security Mechanisms for DSA Networks\n * Cross-Layer Protocol Design\n * Cooperation and Game-Theoretical Protocols for Cognitive Radios\n * Practical Experience and System Implementation\n\nPoster/Demo Submission Instructions:\nSubmission of a demo or a poster requires a written 3-page summary describing the demo or the research results that are to be presented. Submission should go through EDAS. The authors of the accepted posters/demos will have the option of whether to include a 3-page summary in the workshop proceeding, which will be archived by IEEE Xplore.\n\nThe workshop aims to serve as a discussion platform for leading researchers to address the key technical challenges in the design and implementation of dynamic spectrum access technologies. Therefore, the presentations are by invitation-only. However, we might accept a few poster/demo submissions in the presentation session as well.\n\nThe workshop website is http://whitespace2010.cs.ucdavis.edu/.\n\nImportant Dates:\n\nManuscript Submission Due: March 31, 2010, 5pm PDT\nAcceptance Notification: April 30, 2010\nCamera-Ready Paper Due: May 9, 2010\nWorkshop Date: June 21, 2010 (Fifth, IEEE, Workshop, On, Networking, Technologies, For, Softward, Defined, Radio, (, Sdr, ), Networks, \n\n, Looking, for, paper, submissions, ., \n\n, Motivated, by, the, skyrocketing, demand, for, radio, spectrum, ,, facilitated, by, regulatory, policy, movements, ,, and, enabled, by, advances, in, RF, technologies, ,, there, has, been, significant, research, towards, developing, networking, technologies, for, white, spaces, --, the, allocated, but, unutilized, and, under, -, utilized, radio, spectrum, ., One, noticeable, example, is, the, recent, prototype, development, and, FCC, historical, rulings, on, white, spaces, in, the, TV, bands, ., This, workshop, aims, at, providing, a, timely, venue, for, discussing, the, current, ...) None [Fifth IEEE Workshop On Networking Technologies For Softward Defined Radio (Sdr) Networks, Looking for paper submissions., Motivated by the skyrocketing demand for radio spectrum, facilitated by regulatory policy movements, and enabled by advances in RF technologies, there has been significant research towards developing networking technologies for white spaces -- the allocated but unutilized and under-utilized radio spectrum, One noticeable example is the recent prototype development and FCC historical rulings on white spaces in the TV bands, This workshop aims at providing a timely venue for discussing the current activities and findings in the field of cognitive radio networks, dynamic spectrum access, interference prevention, coexistence, and regulatory issues, This workshop will focus on recent advances as well as challenging papers, Areas of interest include but are not limited to:, * Spectrum Sensing and Spectrum Management, * Cognitive Radio Test-Beds and Hardware Prototypes, * DSA/Cognitive Radio Standardization Activities (e.g, IEEE P1900, IEEE 802.22), * Accreditation, Trust, & Security Mechanisms for DSA Networks, * Cross-Layer Protocol Design, * Cooperation and Game-Theoretical Protocols for Cognitive Radios, * Practical Experience and System Implementation, Poster/Demo Submission Instructions:, Submission of a demo or a poster requires a written 3-page summary describing the demo or the research results that are to be presented, Submission should go through EDAS, The authors of the accepted posters/demos will have the option of whether to include a 3-page summary in the workshop proceeding, which will be archived by IEEE Xplore., The workshop aims to serve as a discussion platform for leading researchers to address the key technical challenges in the design and implementation of dynamic spectrum access technologies, Therefore, the presentations are by invitation-only, However, we might accept a few poster/demo submissions in the presentation session as well., The workshop website is http://whitespace2010.cs.ucdavis.edu/., Important Dates:, Manuscript Submission Due: March 31, 2010, 5pm PDT, Acceptance Notification: April 30, 2010, Camera-Ready Paper Due: May 9, 2010, Workshop Date: June 21, 2010] Fifth IEEE Workshop On Networking Technologies For Softward Defined Radio (Sdr) Networks {'March 31, 2010': 'manuscript submission due: march 31, 2010, 5pm pdt', 'April 30, 2010': 'acceptance notification: april 30, 2010', 'May 9, 2010': 'camera-ready paper due: may 9, 2010', 'June 21, 2010': 'workshop date: june 21, 2010'}
31 UT Austin French and Italian Graduate Students Organization Conference UT Austin CALL FOR PAPERS\n \nUT Austin French and Italian Graduate Students Organization Conference\nMapping the Community: Text, Image and Sound\nApril 9-10, 2010\nUniversity of Texas, Austin\n \nThe UT-Austin French and Italian Graduate Student Association proudly announces the Seventh Annual Graduate Student Conference at the Department of French and Italian, University of Texas at Austin on April 9-10, 2010. \n\n This conference aims to evaluate conceptions of community in Italy, France, the Francophone world and the Italian Diaspora from an interdisciplinary perspective. We welcome papers encompassing either linguistics, literature, or both. Participants are asked to address communities, keeping in mind Benedict Anderson's theory of the "imagined community" or Edward Said's "imagined geographies". That is to say that participants should consider the idea that the community is an imagined space or population to which the individual belongs through their perception as part of the group. We aim to develop concepts of the community that encompass textual, visual, and/or aural media. We also wish to consider the development of language as a function of community identity. \n\nThe literature keynote speaker will be Dr. Alec Hargreaves, Director of the Winthrop-King Institute for Contemporary French and Francophone Studies and Ada Belle Winthrop-King Professor of French at Florida State University. Dr. Hargreaves is the author, translator, and editor of several books and articles, including Multi-ethnic France: Immigration, Politics, Culture, and Society (2007), Memory, Empire, and Postcolonialism: Legacies of French Colonialism (2005), Post-colonial Cultures in France (1997).\n\nThe linguistics keynote speaker will be Dr. Gisele Chevalier, Professor of French Linguistics at the UniversitÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ© de Moncton. en contact intense avec l'anglaisÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¬ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ (2007).\n\nPossible topics may include, but are not limited to:\n \n$ Definitions of community\n\n$ Communicative barriers between groups\n\n$ Social, economic, and political groups\n\n$ Regional dialects\n\n$ The effect of language on community belonging or exclusion\n\n$ Linguistic evolution in a given community\n\n$ Shared linguistic traits across communities\n\n$ Issues concerning migration and nomadic communities\n\n$ Levels of belonging (local, regional, national, global)\n\n$ Hybrid identities across communities\n\n$ Community isolation and exclusion within post-colonial states\n\n$ Historical linguistic or social communities\n\n$ Nationalism and community identity\n\n$ Language extinction and disappearing communities\n\n$ Religion, sectarianism, and the creation of spiritual communities\n\n$ Literary movements as social communities\n\n$ The Internet and real and virtual communities \n\n$ Globalization, transnational community, and international language\n\n$ Virtual communication, linguistic registers, and dialects\n\n \nTo be considered, paper proposals, in French, English or Italian, should include:\nA 200-300 word abstract\nYour name\nMailing address\nEmail address\nUniversity affiliation\n \nSuggested deadline for submission is February 25, 2010, but we will respond to submissions as they arrive. Please email paper proposals as a Word document or PDF attachment to: Jonathan Evans, jlevans@mail.utexas.edu\n \nSponsored by The Department of French and Italian, The Center for European Studies and The French and Italian Graduate Student Association (CALL, FOR, PAPERS, \n \n, UT, Austin, French, and, Italian, Graduate, Students, Organization, Conference, \n, Mapping, the, Community, :, Text, ,, Image, and, Sound, \n, April, 9, -, 10, ,, 2010, \n, University, of, Texas, ,, Austin, \n \n, The, UT, -, Austin, French, and, Italian, Graduate, Student, Association, proudly, announces, the, Seventh, Annual, Graduate, Student, Conference, at, the, Department, of, French, and, Italian, ,, University, of, Texas, at, Austin, on, April, 9, -, 10, ,, 2010, ., \n\n , This, conference, aims, to, evaluate, conceptions, of, community, in, Italy, ,, France, ,, the, Francophone, world, and, the, Italian, Diaspora, from, an, interdisciplinary, ...) Austin [CALL FOR PAPERS, , UT Austin French and Italian Graduate Students Organization Conference, Mapping the Community: Text, Image and Sound, April 9-10, 2010, University of Texas, Austin, , The UT-Austin French and Italian Graduate Student Association proudly announces the Seventh Annual Graduate Student Conference at the Department of French and Italian, University of Texas at Austin on April 9-10, 2010, This conference aims to evaluate conceptions of community in Italy, France, the Francophone world and the Italian Diaspora from an interdisciplinary perspective, We welcome papers encompassing either linguistics, literature, or both, Participants are asked to address communities, keeping in mind Benedict Anderson's theory of the "imagined community" or Edward Said's "imagined geographies", That is to say that participants should consider the idea that the community is an imagined space or population to which the individual belongs through their perception as part of the group, We aim to develop concepts of the community that encompass textual, visual, and/or aural media, We also wish to consider the development of language as a function of community identity, , The literature keynote speaker will be Dr, Alec Hargreaves, Director of the Winthrop-King Institute for Contemporary French and Francophone Studies and Ada Belle Winthrop-King Professor of French at Florida State University, Dr, Hargreaves is the author, translator, and editor of several books and articles, including Multi-ethnic France: Immigration, Politics, Culture, and Society (2007), Memory, Empire, and Postcolonialism: Legacies of French Colonialism (2005), Post-colonial Cultures in France (1997)., The linguistics keynote speaker will be Dr, Gisele Chevalier, Professor of French Linguistics at the UniversitÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ© de Moncton, Dr, Chevalier is the author of the medical dictionary Les Mots pour Parler des Maux (2009) and several articles, including de franÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ§ais (2007)., Possible topics may include, but are not limited to:, , $ Definitions of community, $ Communicative barriers between groups, $ Social, economic, and political groups, $ Regional dialects, $ The effect of language on community belonging or exclusion, $ Linguistic evolution in a given community, $ Shared linguistic traits across communities, $ Issues concerning migration and nomadic communities, $ Levels of belonging (local, regional, national, global), $ Hybrid identities across communities, $ Community isolation and exclusion within post-colonial states, $ Historical linguistic or social communities, $ Nationalism and community identity, $ Language extinction and disappearing communities, $ Religion, sectarianism, and the creation of spiritual communities, $ Literary movements as social communities, $ The Internet and real and virtual communities , $ Globalization, transnational community, and international language, $ Virtual communication, linguistic registers, and dialects, , To be considered, paper proposals, in French, English or Italian, should include:, A 200-300 word abstract, Your name, Mailing address, Email address, University affiliation, , Suggested deadline for submission is February 25, 2010, but we will respond to submissions as they arrive, Please email paper proposals as a Word document or PDF attachment to: Jonathan Evans, jlevans@mail.utexas.edu, , Sponsored by The Department of French and Italian, The Center for European Studies and The French and Italian Graduate Student Association] UT Austin French and Italian department of french and italian, university of texas at austin on april 9-10, 2010', 'February 25, 2010': 'suggested deadline for submission is february 25, 2010, but we will respond to submissions 32 First International Workshop on Parallel Software Tools and Tool Infrastructures San Diego, CA ===============================================================================\r\n\r\n Call FOR PAPERS\r\n\r\n First International Workshop on Parallel Software\r\n Tools and Tool Infrastructures (PSTI 2010)\r\n\r\n Held in Conjunction with ICPP 2010,\r\n The 39th International Conference on Parallel Processing\r\n\r\n San Diego, CA, September 13-16, 2010\r\n\r\n http://www.psti-workshop.org\r\n\r\n===============================================================================\r\n\r\nBACKGROUND\r\n\r\nThe advent of multicore and manycore systems requires that programmers\r\nunderstand how to design, write and debug parallel programs effectively.\r\nThe increased complexity of multi-threaded parallel programming on\r\nmulticore platforms requires more insight into program behavior, and\r\nnecessitates the use of tools that can support programmers in migrating\r\nexisting software to multicore platforms, and in writing new multi-threaded\r\nparallel software. Programmers need increasingly sophisticated methods\r\nfor instrumentation, measurement, analysis and modeling of applications.\r\nTo help software developers embrace the multicore revolution, we need\r\nboth sophisticated tools to support parallel software development, and an\r\nextensible tool infrastructure that promotes integration of existing and new\r\ntools, and simplifies information exchange and access.\r\n\r\n\r\nTOPICS\r\n\r\nTopics of interest include, but are not limited to\r\n\r\n * Static and dynamic analysis tools\r\n * Instrumentation, measurement, analysis, and modeling of applications\r\n * Analysis and visualization tools for assisting programmers with parallel\r\n software design\r\n * Active testing tools\r\n * Applications profiling and performance analysis\r\n * Data visualization and analysis infrastructures for interaction of tools\r\n\r\n\r\nPAPER SUBMISSION\r\n\r\nSubmissions should be formatted according to the IEEE standard\r\ndouble-column format with a font size 10 pt or larger and are limited to 10\r\npages in length. Submissions should represent original, substantive\r\nresearch results. At least one author of every accepted paper is required to\r\nattend the conference in order for the paper to be included in the final\r\nproceedings. Proceedings of the workshop will be published in electronic\r\nformat and will be available at the conference.\r\n\r\nSubmit your manuscripts via email to submission@psti-workshop.org\r\n\r\n\r\nKEY DATES\r\n\r\nSubmission Deadline: April 26, 2010 (extended deadline)\r\nNotification of Acceptance: June 7, 2010\r\nFinal Papers Due: June 28, 2010\r\n\r\n\r\nORGANIZATION\r\n\r\nTasneem Brutch, Samsung R&D, USA\r\nKarl Fuerlinger, UC Berkeley, USA\r\nJosef Weidendorfer, TU Munich, Germany\r\n\r\n\r\nPROGRAM COMMITTEE\r\n\r\nRainer Buchty, University of Karlsruhe, Germany\r\nBarbara Chapman, University of Houston, USA\r\nBronis de Supinski, LLNL, USA\r\nMichael Gerndt, TU Muenchen, Germany\r\nGanesh Gopalakrishnan, University Utah, USA\r\nHeike Jagode, University of Tennessee at Knoxville, USA\r\nChristof Klausecker, LMU Munich, Germany\r\nAndreas Knuepfer, TU Dresden, Germany\r\nDieter Kranzlmueller, LMU Munich, Germany\r\nWolfgang Nagel, TU Dresden, Germany\r\nEsmond Ng, LBNL, USA\r\nHeidi Pan, UC Berkeley, USA\r\nPhilip Roth, ORNL, USA\r\nMartin Schulz, LLNL, USA\r\nKoushik Sen, UC Berkeley, USA\r\nJan Treibig, Univeristy of Erlangen-Nuremberg, Germany\r\nCarsten Trinitis, TU Muenchen, Germany\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFURTHER INFORMATION\r\n\r\nSee our website at http://www.psti-workshop.org\r\n\r\n=============================================================================== (=, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, \r\n\r\n , Call, FOR, PAPERS, \r\n\r\n , First, International, Workshop, on, Parallel, Software, \r\n , Tools, and, Tool, Infrastructures, (, PSTI, 2010, ), \r\n\r\n , ...) San Diego [===============================================================================, Call FOR PAPERS, First International Workshop on Parallel Software, Tools and Tool Infrastructures (PSTI 2010), Held in Conjunction with ICPP 2010,, The 39th International Conference on Parallel Processing, San Diego, CA, September 13-16, 2010, http://www.psti-workshop.org, ===============================================================================, BACKGROUND, The advent of multicore and manycore systems requires that programmers, understand how to design, write and debug parallel programs effectively., The increased complexity of multi-threaded parallel programming on, multicore platforms requires more insight into program behavior, and, necessitates the use of tools that can support programmers in migrating, existing software to multicore platforms, and in writing new multi-threaded, parallel software, Programmers need increasingly sophisticated methods, for instrumentation, measurement, analysis and modeling of applications., To help software developers embrace the multicore revolution, we need, both sophisticated tools to support parallel software development, and an, extensible tool infrastructure that promotes integration of existing and new, tools, and simplifies information exchange and access., TOPICS, Topics of interest include, but are not limited to, * Static and dynamic analysis tools, * Instrumentation, measurement, analysis, and modeling of applications, * Analysis and visualization tools for assisting programmers with parallel, software design, * Active testing tools, * Applications profiling and performance analysis, * Data visualization and analysis infrastructures for interaction of tools, PAPER SUBMISSION, Submissions should be formatted according to the IEEE standard, double-column format with a font size 10 pt or larger and are limited to 10, pages in length, Submissions should represent original, substantive, research results, At least one author of every accepted paper is required to, attend the conference in order for the paper to be included in the final, proceedings, Proceedings of the workshop will be published in electronic, format and will be available at the conference., Submit your manuscripts via email to submission@psti-workshop.org, KEY DATES, Submission Deadline: April 26, 2010 (extended deadline), Notification of Acceptance: June 7, 2010, Final Papers Due: June 28, 2010, ORGANIZATION, Tasneem Brutch, Samsung R&D, USA, Karl Fuerlinger, UC Berkeley, USA, Josef Weidendorfer, TU Munich, Germany, PROGRAM COMMITTEE, Rainer Buchty, University of Karlsruhe, Germany, Barbara Chapman, University of Houston, USA, Bronis de Supinski, LLNL, USA, Michael Gerndt, TU Muenchen, Germany, Ganesh Gopalakrishnan, University Utah, USA, Heike Jagode, University of Tennessee at Knoxville, USA, Christof Klausecker, LMU Munich, Germany, Andreas Knuepfer, TU Dresden, Germany, Dieter Kranzlmueller, LMU Munich, Germany, Wolfgang Nagel, TU Dresden, Germany, Esmond Ng, LBNL, USA, Heidi Pan, UC Berkeley, USA, Philip Roth, ORNL, USA, Martin Schulz, LLNL, USA, Koushik Sen, UC Berkeley, USA, Jan Treibig, Univeristy of Erlangen-Nuremberg, Germany, Carsten Trinitis, TU Muenchen, Germany, FURTHER INFORMATION, See our website at http://www.psti-workshop.org, ===============================================================================] First International Workshop on Parallel Software {'The 39th': ' the 39th international conference on parallel processing', 'September 13-16, 2010': ' san diego, ca, september 13-16, 2010', 'April 26, 2010': 'submission deadline: april 26, 2010 (extended deadline)', 'June 28, 2010': 'final papers due: june 28, 2010'}
33 The 5th International Conference on Bio-Inspired Models of Network, Information and Computing Systems Boston, MA, USA Deadline extended to July 30: BIONETICS 2010 (http://www.bionetics.org/)\n\nThe 5th International Conference on Bio-Inspired Models of Network, Information and Computing Systems\n\nDecember 1 - 3, 2010\nBoston, MA, USA\n\nTechnical cooperation with Create-Net, ACM SIGSIM and Springer\n\nBIONETICS 2010 aims to provide a world-leading and unique opportunity for bringing together researchers and practitioners from diverse disciplines that seek the understanding of the fundamental principles and design strategies in biological systems and leverage those understandings to build bio-inspired systems. We are soliciting high-quality original papers in the following topics (but not limited to): \n\n* Signal/information processing and communication models in biological systems\n* Bio-inspired formal models and methods\n* Bio-inspired algorithms and mechanisms\n* Bio-inspired software and hardware systems\n* Biomimetics, bioenginereing and synthetic biological systems\n* Modeling and simulation of bio-inspired systems, biological systems and synthetic biological systems\n* Self-* properties in bio-inspired systems, biological systems and synthetic biological systems\n* Design and performance issues in bio-inspired systems and synthetic biological systems\n* Tools, testbeds and deployment aspects in bio-inspired systems and synthetic biological systems\n* Real-world applications and standardization of bio-inspired systems and synthetic biological systems\n* Socially-aware, game theoretic and other metaphor-driven interdisciplinary approaches to bio-inspired systems and synthetic biological systems\n\nApplication domains include, but not limited to, autonomic computing, bioinformatics, biological engineering, computer networks, computer vision, data mining, green computing and networking, grid/cloud computing, intelligent agents, mechanical engineering, molecular communication, nano-scale computing and networking, optimization, pervasive computing, robotics, security, software engineering, and systems engineering.\n\nPaper Submission: \n\nAuthors are invited to submit papers in the following categories: \n\n * Regular papers: Up to 15 pages\n * Short papers: Up to 2 pages\n * Work-in-progress (WIP) papers: Up to 6 pages\n * Demo papers: Up to 4 pages\n\nPapers must follow the Springer LNICST format. Please visit http://www.bionetics.org/submission.shtml for detailed submission instructions. \n\nImportant Dates: \n\n Regular paper submission due: July 30 2010\n Short, WIP and demo paper submission due: September 19 2010\n Notification of acceptance for regular papers: September 12 2010\n Notification of acceptance for short, WIP and demo papers: September 30 2010\n Camera ready due: October 10\n\nPublication: \n\nAll accepted paper will be published by Springer. A selected number of best papers will be considered for publication in leading journals such as:\n\n * ACM Trans. on Autonomous and Adaptive Systems (http://taas.acm.org/),\n * Int'l Journal of Autonomous and Adaptive Communications Systems (http://www.inderscience.com/browse/index.php?journalCODE=ijaacs), \n * Elsevier Nano Communication Networks Journal (http://www.elsevier.com/locate/nanocomnet), \n * Int'l Journal of Software Engineering and Knowledge Engineering (http://www.worldscinet.com/ijseke/ijseke.shtml), \n * Journal of Ambient Intelligence and Humanized Computing (http://www.springer.com/engineering/journal/12652), and \n * Journal of Bioinformatics and Computational Biology (http://www.worldscinet.com/jbcb/). \n\nKeynote Speakers:\n\n * Radhika Nagpal (Harvard University)\n * Cheng Li (Harvard School of Public Health and Dana-Farber Cancer Institute)\n * Ian F. Akyildiz (Georgia Institute of Technology)\n * Karl Lieberherr (Northeastern University)\n * Thilo Gross (Max Planck Institute for the Physics of Complex Systems)\n\nSpecial Tracks (http://www.bionetics.org/sp/):\n\n * Artificial Intelligence and Software Engineering\n * Artificial Life and Bio-inspired Robotics\n * Biologically-inspired Communications for Nanonetworks\n * Bioinformatics\n * Bio-Inspired Machine Vision\n * Game Theory and its Applications\n * Network based computation\n * State-Topology Coevolution in Adaptive Networks\n\nGeneral Chair:\n\n Junichi Suzuki, University of Massachusetts, Boston, USA\n\nPC Chair:\n\n Tadashi Nakano, Osaka University, Japan\n\nSteering Committee:\n\n Tatsuya Suda, chair, University of California, Irvine, USA\n Iacopo Carreras, Create-Net, Italy\n Imrich Chlamtac, Create-Net and University of Trento, Italy\n Falko Dressler, University of Erlangen, Germany\n\nPC Vice Chairs:\n\n Ozgur Akan, Middle East Technical University, Turkey\n Eduard AlarcÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ³n, Boston [Deadline extended to July 30: BIONETICS 2010 (http://www.bionetics.org/), The 5th International Conference on Bio-Inspired Models of Network, Information and Computing Systems, December 1 - 3, 2010, Boston, MA, USA, Technical cooperation with Create-Net, ACM SIGSIM and Springer, BIONETICS 2010 aims to provide a world-leading and unique opportunity for bringing together researchers and practitioners from diverse disciplines that seek the understanding of the fundamental principles and design strategies in biological systems and leverage those understandings to build bio-inspired systems, We are soliciting high-quality original papers in the following topics (but not limited to): , * Signal/information processing and communication models in biological systems, * Bio-inspired formal models and methods, * Bio-inspired algorithms and mechanisms, * Bio-inspired software and hardware systems, * Biomimetics, bioenginereing and synthetic biological systems, * Modeling and simulation of bio-inspired systems, biological systems and synthetic biological systems, * Self-* properties in bio-inspired systems, biological systems and synthetic biological systems, * Design and performance issues in bio-inspired systems and synthetic biological systems, * Tools, testbeds and deployment aspects in bio-inspired systems and synthetic biological systems, * Real-world applications and standardization of bio-inspired systems and synthetic biological systems, * Socially-aware, game theoretic and other metaphor-driven interdisciplinary approaches to bio-inspired systems and synthetic biological systems, Application domains include, but not limited to, autonomic computing, bioinformatics, biological engineering, computer networks, computer vision, data mining, green computing and networking, grid/cloud computing, intelligent agents, mechanical engineering, molecular communication, nano-scale computing and networking, optimization, pervasive computing, robotics, security, software engineering, and systems engineering., Paper Submission: , Authors are invited to submit papers in the following categories: , * Regular papers: Up to 15 pages, * Short papers: Up to 2 pages, * Work-in-progress (WIP) papers: Up to 6 pages, * Demo papers: Up to 4 pages, Papers must follow the Springer LNICST format, Please visit http://www.bionetics.org/submission.shtml for detailed submission instructions, , Important Dates: , Regular paper submission due: July 30 2010, Short, WIP and demo paper submission due: September 19 2010, Notification of acceptance for regular papers: September 12 2010, Notification of acceptance for short, WIP and demo papers: September 30 2010, Camera ready due: October 10, Publication: , All accepted paper will be published by Springer, A selected number of best papers will be considered for publication in leading journals such as:, * ACM Trans, on Autonomous and Adaptive Systems (http://taas.acm.org/),, * Int'l Journal of Autonomous and Adaptive Communications Systems (http://www.inderscience.com/browse/index.php?journalCODE=ijaacs), , * Elsevier Nano Communication Networks Journal (http://www.elsevier.com/locate/nanocomnet), , * Int'l Journal of Software Engineering and Knowledge Engineering (http://www.worldscinet.com/ijseke/ijseke.shtml), , * Journal of Ambient Intelligence and Humanized Computing (http://www.springer.com/engineering/journal/12652), and , * Journal of Bioinformatics and Computational Biology (http://www.worldscinet.com/jbcb/), Keynote Speakers:, * Radhika Nagpal (Harvard University), * Cheng Li (Harvard School of Public Health and Dana-Farber Cancer Institute), * Ian F, Akyildiz (Georgia Institute of Technology), * Karl Lieberherr (Northeastern University), * Thilo Gross (Max Planck Institute for the Physics of Complex Systems), Special Tracks (http://www.bionetics.org/sp/):, * Artificial Intelligence and Software Engineering, * Artificial Life and Bio-inspired Robotics, * Biologically-inspired Communications for Nanonetworks, * Bioinformatics, * Bio-Inspired Machine Vision, * Game Theory and its Applications, * Network based computation, * State-Topology Coevolution in Adaptive Networks, General Chair:, Junichi Suzuki, University of Massachusetts, Boston, USA, PC Chair:, Tadashi Nakano, Osaka University, Japan, Steering Committee:, Tatsuya Suda, chair, University of California, Irvine, USA, Iacopo Carreras, Create-Net, Italy, Imrich Chlamtac, Create-Net and University of Trento, Italy, Falko Dressler, University of Erlangen, Germany, PC Vice Chairs:, Ozgur Akan, Middle East Technical University, Turkey, Eduard AlarcÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ³n, 34 Fifth IEEE Workshop On Wireless Mesh Networks Boston, USA Wireless mesh networking is attracting significant interest as a low-cost networking platform to support ubiquitous broadband access in home networks, enterprise networks, or larger, community or metro-scale networks. Many universities and industrial labs have on-going research projects on various aspects of mesh networking, including architectures, protocols, services and applications. Several startups are building mesh networking platforms and deploying services.\n\nFifth IEEE Workshop On Wireless Mesh Networks\n\nFollowing the success of the first four IEEE Workshops on Wireless Mesh Networks, WiMesh 2010 will be a one-day forum for meeting, presenting and discussing core technical issues and current research problems in wireless mesh networking. Given its one-day, highly interactive format, papers presenting early innovative ideas are very welcome. Topics include, but are not limited to:\n\n * Experiences with the deployment of wireless mesh networks\n * Wireless mesh network performance\n * Integration of wireless mesh networks with wired/wireless networks (802.11, white space, etc.)\n * Experimental validation of wireless mesh network algorithms\n * Architectures, protocols, and algorithms for wireless mesh networks\n * Localization and mobility in wireless mesh networks\n * Security, privacy, and trustworthiness\n * Protocols exploiting novel technologies such as UWB, MIMO, directional antennas, software radios\n * Wireless mesh network testbeds\n\nImportant dates:\nPaper submission deadline: Friday April 2, 2010\nNotification of acceptance: Friday May 2, 2010\nCamera-ready papers due: Monday May 10, 2010\nWorkshop: Wednesday July 21, 2010\n\nSubmission guidelines: \nAll paper submissions will be handled electronically via the EDAS system and should conform to the following requirements:\nThe paper must be formatted according to IEEE conference proceedings style in two-column format, have a maximum of 6 (six) 8.5"x11" pages (including figures, tables, and references) using 10-point size or greater and must be submitted in PDF format.\n\nProgram Co-Chairs:\nTheodoros Salonidis, Thomson\nRomit Roy Choudhury, Duke University (Wireless, mesh, networking, is, attracting, significant, interest, as, a, low, -, cost, networking, platform, to, support, ubiquitous, broadband, access, in, home, networks, ,, enterprise, networks, ,, or, larger, ,, community, or, metro, -, scale, networks, ., Many, universities, and, industrial, labs, have, on, -, going, research, projects, on, various, aspects, of, mesh, networking, ,, including, architectures, ,, protocols, ,, services, and, applications, ., Several, startups, are, building, mesh, networking, platforms, and, deploying, services, ., \n\n, Fifth, IEEE, Workshop, On, Wireless, Mesh, Networks, \n\n, Following, the, success, of, the, first, four, IEEE, Workshops, on, Wireless, Mesh, Networks, ,, WiMesh, 2010, will, ...) None [Wireless mesh networking is attracting significant interest as a low-cost networking platform to support ubiquitous broadband access in home networks, enterprise networks, or larger, community or metro-scale networks, Many universities and industrial labs have on-going research projects on various aspects of mesh networking, including architectures, protocols, services and applications, Several startups are building mesh networking platforms and deploying services., Fifth IEEE Workshop On Wireless Mesh Networks, Following the success of the first four IEEE Workshops on Wireless Mesh Networks, WiMesh 2010 will be a one-day forum for meeting, presenting and discussing core technical issues and current research problems in wireless mesh networking, Given its one-day, highly interactive format, papers presenting early innovative ideas are very welcome, Topics include, but are not limited to:, * Experiences with the deployment of wireless mesh networks, * Wireless mesh network performance, * Integration of wireless mesh networks with wired/wireless networks (802.11, white space, etc.), * Experimental validation of wireless mesh network algorithms, * Architectures, protocols, and algorithms for wireless mesh networks, * Localization and mobility in wireless mesh networks, * Security, privacy, and trustworthiness, * Protocols exploiting novel technologies such as UWB, MIMO, directional antennas, software radios, * Wireless mesh network testbeds, Important dates:, Paper submission deadline: Friday April 2, 2010, Notification of acceptance: Friday May 2, 2010, Camera-ready papers due: Monday May 10, 2010, Workshop: Wednesday July 21, 2010, Submission guidelines: , All paper submissions will be handled electronically via the EDAS system and should conform to the following requirements:, The paper must be formatted according to IEEE conference proceedings style in two-column format, have a maximum of 6 (six) 8.5"x11" pages (including figures, tables, and references) using 10-point size or greater and must be submitted in PDF format., Program Co-Chairs:, Theodoros Salonidis, Thomson, Romit Roy Choudhury, Duke University] Fifth IEEE Workshop On Wireless Mesh Networks {'Friday April 2, 2010': 'paper submission deadline: friday april 2, 2010', 'Friday May 2, 2010': 'notification of acceptance: friday may 2, 2010', 'Monday May 10, 2010': 'camera-ready papers due: monday may 10, 2010', 'Wednesday July 21, 2010': 'workshop: wednesday july 21, 2010'}
35 The 38th Annual ACM SIGPLAN-SIGACT Symposium on Principles of Programming Languages San, Diego, CA, USA Scope\n\nThe 38th Annual ACM SIGPLAN-SIGACT Symposium on Principles of Programming Languages\n\nThe annual Symposium on Principles of Programming Languages is a forum for the discussion of all aspects of programming languages and systems, with emphasis on how principles underpin practice. Both theoretical and experimental papers are welcome, on topics ranging from formal frameworks to experience reports.\n\nImportant dates\n\nPaper submission \tJuly 14, 2010 (Wednesday)\nAuthor response period \tSeptember 15-16, 2010 (Wednesday-Thursday)\nAuthor notification \tOctober 8, 2010 (Friday)\nCamera ready \tNovember 9, 2010 (Tuesday)\nConference \tJanuary 26-28, 2011\n\nOrganizers\n\nGeneral Chair: \tThomas Ball\nMicrosoft Research\nOne Microsoft Way, Redmond, WA 98052, USA.\ntball@microsoft.com\n\nProgram Chair:\n\t\nMooly Sagiv\nSchreiber 317, School of Computer Science\nTel-Aviv University, Tel-Aviv 69978, Israel\nmsagiv@post.tau.ac.il\n\nProgram Committee:\n\t \nRadhia Cousot \tÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ°cole USA [Scope, The 38th Annual ACM SIGPLAN-SIGACT Symposium on Principles of Programming Languages, The annual Symposium on Principles of Programming Languages is a forum for the discussion of all aspects of programming languages and systems, with emphasis on how principles underpin practice, Both theoretical and experimental papers are welcome, on topics ranging from formal frameworks to experience reports., Important dates, Paper submission \tJuly 14, 2010 (Wednesday), Author response period \tSeptember 15-16, 2010 (Wednesday-Thursday), Author notification \tOctober 8, 2010 (Friday),
