de Madrid\nPaul Buitelaar DERI, National University of Ireland, Galway\nPhilipp Cimiano Delft University of Technology\nRazvan Bunescu University of Texas at Austin\nRene Witte Concordia University MontrÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ©al\nRoxana Girju University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign\nSaif Mohammad University of Maryland\nSamer Hassan University of North Texas\nSÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¶ren Auer Leipzig University\nTonio Wandmacher CEA, Paris (COLING, 2010, \n, CALL, FOR, PAPERS, \n\n, 2nd, Workshop, on, \n, Collaboratively, Constructed, Semantic, Resources, \n\n, Beijing, \n, August, 28th, ,, 2010, \n, http://www.ukp.tu, -, darmstadt.de, /, scientific, -, community, /, coling-2010-workshop/, \n\n\n, Keywords, :, \n, Wikipedia, ,, Wiktionary, ,, Mechanical, Turk, ,, Games, with, a, purpose, ,, \n, Folksonomies, ,, Twitter, ,, Social, Networks, \n\n\n, INTRODUCTION, \n\n, The, workshop, builds, upon, the, success, of, the, first, ACL, ", The, People, 's, Web, \n, meets, NLP, ", Workshop, in, 2009, that, attracted, 21, submissions, ., Accepted, \n, submissions, included, papers, on, Wikipedia, [, 1, ], ,, Wiktionary, [, 2, ], ...) Beijing [COLING 2010, CALL FOR PAPERS, 2nd Workshop on, Collaboratively Constructed Semantic Resources, Beijing, August 28th, 2010, http://www.ukp.tu-darmstadt.de/scientific-community/coling-2010-workshop/, Keywords:, Wikipedia, Wiktionary, Mechanical Turk, Games with a purpose,, Folksonomies, Twitter, Social Networks, INTRODUCTION, The workshop builds upon the success of the first ACL "The People's Web, meets NLP" Workshop in 2009 that attracted 21 submissions, Accepted, submissions included papers on Wikipedia [1], Wiktionary [2], Mechanical, Turk [3], and game-based construction of semantic resources [4], This, clearly demonstrates a substantial and growing interest of the NLP, community in collaboratively constructed semantic resources (CSRs),, also evidenced by the increasing number of publications in this area, and the EMNLP 2009 Web 2.0 track, In many works, CSRs have been used, to overcome the knowledge acquisition bottleneck and coverage problems, pertinent to conventional lexical semantic resources, The greatest, popularity in this respect can so far certainly be attributed to, Wikipedia [1], However, other resources, such as folksonomies or the, multilingual collaboratively constructed dictionary Wiktionary, have, also shown great potential, Thus, the scope of the workshop deliberately, includes any collaboratively constructed resource, not only Wikipedia., Effective deployment of CSRs to enhance NLP introduces a pressing need, to address a set of fundamental challenges, e.g, the interoperability, with existing resources, or the quality of the extracted lexical, semantic knowledge, Interoperability between resources is crucial as, no single resource provides perfect coverage, The quality of CSRs is, a fundamental issue, as they lack editorial control and entries are, often incomplete, Thus, techniques for link prediction [5] or, information extraction [6] have been proposed to guide the "crowds", while constructing resources of better quality., [1] Olena Medelyan, David Milne, Catherine Legg and Ian H, Witten., Mining meaning from Wikipedia., In: International Journal of Human-Computer Studies, 67(9), 2009., [2] Torsten Zesch, Christof Mueller and Iryna Gurevych, Extracting Lexical Semantic Knowledge from Wikipedia and Wiktionary, Proceedings of the Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation, (LREC), 2008., http://www.ukp.tu-darmstadt.de/software/jwpl/, http://www.ukp.tu-darmstadt.de/software/jwktl/, [3] Rion Snow, Brendan O'Connor, Daniel Jurafsky and Andrew Y, Ng., Cheap and Fast---But is it Good? Evaluating Non-Expert Annotations, for Natural Language Tasks., Proceedings of EMNLP, 2008., [4] Luis von Ahn and Laura Dabbish., General Techniques for Designing Games with a Purpose., Communications of the ACM, 2008., [5] Rada Mihalcea and Andras Csomai, Wikify!: Linking Documents to Encyclopedic Knowledge., Proceedings of the Sixteenth ACM Conference on Information and, Knowledge Management, CIKM 2007., [6] Daniel S, Weld et al., Intelligence in Wikipedia., Twenty-Third Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI), 2008., TOPICS, The workshop will bring together researchers from different worlds, for, example those using collaboratively constructed resources as sources of, lexical semantic information for NLP purposes such as information, retrieval, named entity recognition, or keyword extraction, and those, using NLP techniques to improve the resources or extract and analyze, different types of lexical semantic information from them, We will, especially welcome contributions of interdisciplinary nature, e.g, those, applying discourse analysis techniques from computational linguistics to, the content of CSRs to better understand their properties., Specific topics include but are not limited to:, * Analysis of collaboratively constructed resources, such as wiki-based, platforms, folksonomies, Twitter, or social networks;, * Using collaboratively constructed resources for NLP purposes such, as information retrieval, text categorization, information, extraction, etc.;, * Using special features of collaboratively constructed resources to, create novel resource types, for example revision-based corpora,, simplified versions of resources, etc.;, * Analyzing the structure of collaboratively constructed resources, related to their use in NLP;, * Interoperability of collaboratively constructed resources with, conventional lexical semantic resources and between themselves;, * Mining social and collaborative content for constructing structured, semantic resources and the corresponding tools;, ...] The workshop builds upon the success of the first ACL "The People's Web {'August 28th, 2010': 'august 28th, 2010', 'May 30, 2010': 'paper submission deadline (full and short): may 30, 2010', 'June 30, 2010': 'notification of acceptance of papers: june 30, 2010', 'July 10, 2010': 'camera-ready copy of papers due: july 10, 2010'}
85 The Ninth Biennial Conference of the Association for Machine Translation in the Americas Denver, Colorado AMTA-2010\n\n The Ninth Biennial Conference of\n the Association for Machine Translation in the Americas\n\n Westin Tabor Center, Denver, Colorado\n Held October 31 - November 05, 2010\n\n\n PRELIMINARY ANNOUNCEMENT and CALL FOR PAPERS\n\n MACHINE TRANSLATION IN THE PRODUCTION PIPELINE\n\nThe ninth biennial conference of the Association for Machine Translation\nin the Americas (AMTA-2010) will be held at the Westin Tabor Center in\nDenver Colorado, Sunday, October 31 through Friday, November 5. AMTA-2010 will take place immediately following the 51st Annual Conference of the\nAmerican Translators Association (ATA), also taking place in Denver,\nOctober 27-30. The two conferences are planning multiple coordinated\nevents around joint topics of interest. These are designed to deepen MT\nresearchers' and developers' understanding of the needs of the commercial\ntranslation industry and human translators, while also fostering\ntranslators' understanding of modern MT technology and the role of\nadvanced translation automation in commercial translation processes.\n\nIn addition to a research track, the main AMTA-2010 conference program\nwill include presentation tracks for government and commercial users of MT\nand a "Technology Showcase" of commercial and research-stage MT\ntechnology. The research program will include a peer-reviewed competitive "Student Research Workshop" designed to highlight and foster the work of\nthe next generation of MT researchers. Tutorials will be held on Sunday,\nOctober 31, and workshops will take place primarily on Thursday and\nFriday, November 4-5.\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nCall for MT Research Papers at AMTA-2010\n\nContact: Hassan Sawaf (hassan (at) sawaf.de)\n\nMachine Translation continues to be one of the most active research areas\nwithin Natural Language Processing. MT evaluations, such as those\nconducted by NIST, provide ample evidence that the field of MT continues\nto grow and attract more and more researchers. Data-driven approaches\nhave become particularly fashionable in recent years. These approaches\nhave generated systems that have been the top performers in recent\ncomparative evaluations. Furthermore, the challenges of building\ncompetitive MT systems have been significantly reduced with the\nintroduction of open source toolkits such as GIZA++ and MOSES. This\ndevelopment, exciting as it is, also bears the danger of introducing\nuniformity into MT research. AMTA aims to promote diversity in MT\nresearch and actively seeks research papers across the entire range of the MT research spectrum for the AMTA-2010 research program. We solicit\nsubmissions in English of unpublished papers describing original research\non all aspects of Machine Translation. We particularly encourage\nsubmissions on topics related to the conference theme of MT applied within commercial translation settings.\n\n\nImportant dates:\n\n- Submission deadline: Monday, May 24\n- Notifications of acceptance: Monday, July 5\n- Final "camera-ready" versions: Monday, August 16\n\n\nTopics of interest include but are not limited to:\n\n- Advances in data-driven MT (Statistical MT, Example-based MT, etc.)\n- Advances in rule-based MT (Transfer-based MT, Interlingual MT, etc.)\n- Lexicon and grammar acquisition and induction\n- Hybrid approaches that integrate and unify aspects of rule-based MT and\n statistical MT\n- MT for resource-poor languages\n- MT on resource-limited machinery (e.g. PDAs)\n- Distributed architectures for large data MT\n- Speech-to-speech or speech-to-text MT\n- MT with OCR\n- MT for communication (chats, blogs, social networks)\n- Customization and adaptation of high-performance MT systems\n- Deep integration of MT technology within translation and localization\n pipelines\n- MT Evaluation\n\n\nSubmission Instructions:\n\nPapers should not be longer than 10 pages and should be in pdf format. Style files (Latex and MS Word) will be posted on the conference web-page\nat:\n\nhttp://amta2010.amtaweb.org/\n\nTo allow for blind reviewing, please do not include author names and\naffiliations within the paper and avoid obvious self-references.\n\nDetailed submission instructions will be posted on the conference website\nin the near future and will be included in future announcements.\n\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nMT User Presentations: Commercial Users and Translators\n\nContact: Mike Dillinger ( mike@translationOptimization.com )\n\nThe Commercial User track will focus on how MT can meet business needs\nsuch as just-in-time localization of critical information, provisioning of\ntechnical support information, or creation of preliminary translations for post-editing. Submissions should focus on the use of MT in a business\nsetting and how it is integrated with other technologies to support\nbusiness goals.\n\nImportant dates:\n\n- Submissions due: Monday, June 28\n- Notification of acceptance: Monday, July 12\n- Final "camera-ready" versions due: Monday, August 16\n\n\nTopics of interest include but are not limited to:\n\n- Integrating MT and human translation\n- Post-editing experiences and data about productivity\n- ROI analyses of post-editing versus translation\n- Use of MT to provide localization of data-driven, dynamic, or\n user-specific information\n- Use of MT to reduce localization time and/or cost\n- Ways in which MT can be used to increase the scope of globalization\n projects\n- Managing change when implementing MT systems\n- Open-source and low-cost MT tools: are they realistic and is there a\n market for them?\n\n\nWhat to submit:\n\nIdeal presentations will clearly identify a business need and describe how\nMT meets those needs, with a candid assessment of its strengths and\nlimitations for that particular usage. Submissions should be 250-500 word summaries and may be sent directly in e-mail or as attachments in RTF\nformat.\n\n\nHow to submit:\n\nSend submissions or questions by email to Mike Dillinger (mike@translationOptimization.com) by Monday, June 28.\n\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nMT User Presentations: Government Users and Translation Professionals\n\nContacts: Nick Bemish ( Nicholas.Bemish@dia.mil )\n Chuck Simmons ( Charles.Simmons@wpafb.af.mil )\n\n\nAMTA Government User presenters and participants will focus on the\nstrategic nature and use of Machine Translation in governmental\norganizations. Most governmental entities are providing a benefit to\ntheir customers, who require them to translate large volumes of\ninformation and to make it available across multiple languages and varied\nnetwork architectures. The need for language translation technology\nwithin governmental organizations is diverse and sometimes compartmented.\nGovernments are looking to advances in Machine Translation technology,\nwhich help them deliver information not only from the native languages of various countries but also into those other languages. In\nturn, the information delivered helps the governments to understand social\nand political activities in context. In an age when significant volumes\nof data are available in many languages, it is necessary to look to\nautomated alternatives, which assist the linguist and enable the human\ntranslation process.\n\nFor this year's AMTA conference, we are asking government participants to\nconsider topics that address the strategic challenges of applying MT tools\nand applications in their programs and processes. We are looking for\nrepresentation from all government organizations that face language\nchallenges, including: Defense, Homeland Security, Health and Human\nServices, Human Resources, Commerce, Labor, Energy, Judiciary, Business,\nTrade, Transportation, and many others. Within the governmental\norganizations we request the attendance of leaders or their\nrepresentatives, who can address challenging topics ranging among:\n\n1. Acquisition strategies that include policies directed towards implementation of MT\n2. Funding priorities that stress the need for metrics to ensure adequate return on investment (ROI)\n3. Requirements development which include a broad audience of users\n across the federal workspace\n4. Computer systems and network architectures that support inclusion of\n MT tools and any significant integration and security challenges\n5. Research and development leading to the advancement of tools that\n support less commonly used languages or minimizes gaps\n6. Program management strategies and how they apply to the integration\n and acceptance of MT tool usage\n7. Case studies on examples of MT use and how it impacts the\n organizations ability to share content\n8. Strategic views and objectives pertaining to challenges with respect\n to MT programs and the employment of MT tools (e.g., IT, personnel,\n implementation)\n9. Implementation strategies that factor into MT use as a process\n supporting human translation (pre-translation/post-editing)\n\nThe sessions will be structured to provide open and constructive dialogue\namong attendees with diverse technical backgrounds and areas of expertise. A secondary objective of this approach is to establish longer-term\nconnections among participants and foster new cooperative efforts.\n\n\nImportant dates:\n\n- Submissions due: Monday, June 28\n- Notification of acceptance: Monday, July 12\n- Final "camera-ready" versions due: Monday, August 16\n\n\nWhat to submit:\n\nIdeal proposals should include information on strategic views and\nobjectives pertaining to MT programs; employment of MT tools and\nsignificant challenges; as well as information on achievable gains through usage and/or metrics. Submissions should be 250-400 word summaries and\nmay be sent directly in e-mail or as attachments in RTF format.\n\n\nHow to submit:\n\nSend submissions and questions to Government User program chairs, Nicholas Bemish at Nicholas.Bemish@dia.mil and Chuck Simmons at\nCharles.Simmons@wpafb.af.mil by Monday, June 28.\n\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nStudent Research Workshop\n\nContact: Stephan Vogel ( stephan.vogel@cs.cmu.edu )\n\nAMTA-2010 will feature a Student Research Workshop, which will be embedded\nas an integral part of the research program at the conference. Students\nat all levels of study (undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate) are\ninvited to submit papers describing their research work. To qualify, the\nmain author of the paper must be a student or a post-doc. Both completed\nwork as well as work in progress is eligible for submission. Submissions\nwill be competitively reviewed by a committee consisting of both advanced\nMT students and senior researchers, in a process similar to the reviewing\nof submissions to the main AMTA-2010 research program. We hope to provide travel and participation financial support to the students selected for\npresentations. Details will be posted on the conference website when available.\n\n\nImportant dates:\n\n- Submission deadline: Monday, May 24\n- Notifications of acceptance: Monday, July 5\n- Final "camera-ready" versions: Monday, August 16\n\n\nTopics:\n\nAll topics related to MT research are welcome. See the list of topics for\nthe MT Research Program above for a listing of sample topics of interest.\n\n\nWhat to submit:\n\nPapers should not be longer than 10 pages, formatted using the provided\nstyle for research papers, and in pdf format. Style files (Latex and MS\nWord) will be posted on the conference web-page at:\n\nhttp://amta2010.amtaweb.org/\n\nTo allow for blind reviewing, please do not include author names and affiliations within the paper and avoid obvious self-references.\n\nDetailed submission instructions will be posted on the conference website\nin the near future and will be included in future announcements.\n\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nCall for Proposals for Workshops, Tutorials and Panels at AMTA-2010\n\nContact: George Foster ( george.foster@nrc.gc.ca )\n\nAMTA 2010 is seeking proposals for workshops, tutorials and plenary panels\non all topics related to MT. We particularly encourage proposals on\ntopics related to the conference theme of MT applied within commercial\ntranslation settings.\n\nTutorials will be held on Sunday, October 31, immediately preceding the\nmain conference. Workshops will be held on Thursday and Friday, November\n4-5, immediately following the main conference. Selected panels will be\nan integral part of the main conference.\n\n\nAims:\n\nTutorials at AMTA conferences are a forum for experts in MT and MT-related areas to deliver concentrated training on a topic of interest in half-day\n(or occasionally full-day) teaching sessions. Tutorials provide\nbackground that helps conference participants (especially newcomers to the field) understand the conference program, and/or enrich their\nunderstanding of particular technical, applied, and business matters\nsurrounding research, development and use of MT and translation\ntechnology.\n\nAMTA workshops are intended to provide the opportunity for MT-related\ncommunities of interest to spend focused time together advancing the state\nof thinking or the state of practice in their area of interest or\nendeavor.\n\nPanel sessions within the main conference program provide an opportunity\nfor a select number of experts to provide their perspective and hold a\ndiscussion on a concrete topic of interest or developing issue within the\nfield of MT.\n\nDue to AMTA 2010's collocation with the ATA meeting, we are particularly\ninterested in proposals related to commercialization of MT and/or its use\nby professional translators. However, any themes connected to MT\nresearch, development, deployment, use, and evaluation are welcome.\n\n\nWhat to submit:\n\nProposals for workshops, tutorials and panel sessions should be submitted\nby June 30, 2010 to George Foster (george.foster@nrc.gc.ca). They should\ninclude the proposed format (workshop, tutorial or panel), a title, a\none-page description of the proposed content, technical requirements and\nthe expected number of participants. In the case of a workshop, the\nproposal should also include dates for important milestones (call for\npapers, recruitment of speakers, etc.), and whether this is an ongoing or\nnew workshop. Workshop and Tutorial proposals must also include a signed\ncopy of the AMTA Workshop or Tutorial Policy and Leader Agreement Form. The appropriate forms will be posted on the conference web-page at:\n\nhttp://amta2010.amtaweb.org/\n\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nCall for AMTA-2010 Sponsorships\n\nHelp support the AMTA Mission while demonstrating your leadership in the\nfuture of MT!\n\nSponsorship of AMTA-2010 is a tax-deductible donation. AMTA is a 501-(c)-3 non-profit educational association.\n\nAll sponsorship levels receive:\n- Logo with hyperlink to sponsor website on website: http://amta2010.amtaweb.org/\n- Logo and name in conference program\n- Acknowledgement at Conference Opening\n- One piece of collateral included in Conference Bag\n\nPlease contact Sponsorship Chair Laurie Gerber (lgerber@amtaweb.org) for a sponsorship prospectus. Help us provide continuous internet service for\nparticipants! Support a workshop! Snag the hottest brand real estate at\nthe conference - the badgeholder! Several new sponsor-able items are\navailable this time, including your logo on the hotel room keys!\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\n\n\n AMTA-2010\n\n The Ninth Biennial Conference \n of the Association for Machine Translation in the Americas\n\n Westin Tabor Center, Denver, Colorado \n October 31 - November 05, 2010\n\n\n PRELIMINARY ANNOUNCEMENT and CALL FOR PAPERS\n\n MACHINE TRANSLATION IN THE PRODUCTION PIPELINE\n\nThe ninth biennial conference of the Association for Machine Translation in\nthe Americas (AMTA-2010) will be held at the Westin Tabor Center in Denver\nColorado, Sunday, October 31 through Friday, November 5. AMTA-2010 will take\nplace immediately following the 51st Annual Conference of the American\nTranslators Association (ATA), also taking place in Denver, October 27-30.\nThe two conferences are planning multiple coordinated events around joint\ntopics of interest. These are designed to deepen MT researchers' and\ndevelopers' understanding of the needs of the commercial translation industry\nand human translators, while also fostering translators' understanding of\nmodern MT technology and the role of advanced translation automation in\ncommercial translation processes.\n\nIn addition to a research track, the main AMTA-2010 conference program will \ninclude presentation tracks for government and commercial users of MT and a\n"Technology Showcase" of commercial and research-stage MT technology. The\nresearch program will include a peer-reviewed competitive "Student Research \nWorkshop" designed to highlight and foster the work of the next generation of\nMT researchers. Tutorials will be held on Sunday, October 31, and workshops\nwill take place primarily on Thursday and Friday, November 4-5.\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nCall for MT Research Papers at AMTA-2010\n\nContact: Hassan Sawaf (hassan (at) sawaf.de)\n\nMachine Translation continues to be one of the most active research areas\nwithin Natural Language Processing. MT evaluations, such as those conducted\nby NIST, provide ample evidence that the field of MT continues to grow and\nattract more and more researchers. Data-driven approaches have become\nparticularly fashionable in recent years. These approaches have generated\nsystems that have been the top performers in recent comparative evaluations.\nFurthermore, the challenges of building competitive MT systems have been\nsignificantly reduced with the introduction of open source toolkits such as\nGIZA++ and MOSES. This development, exciting as it is, also bears the danger\nof introducing uniformity into MT research. AMTA aims to promote diversity in\nMT research and actively seeks research papers across the entire range of the\nMT research spectrum for the AMTA-2010 research program. We solicit\nsubmissions in English of unpublished papers describing original research on\nall aspects of Machine Translation. We particularly encourage submissions on\ntopics related to the conference theme of MT applied within commercial\ntranslation settings.\n\n\nImportant dates:\n\n- Submission deadline: Monday, May 24\n- Notifications of acceptance: Monday, July 5\n- Final "camera-ready" versions: Monday, August 16\n\n\nTopics of interest include but are not limited to:\n\n- Advances in data-driven MT (Statistical MT, Example-based MT, etc.)\n- Advances in rule-based MT (Transfer-based MT, Interlingual MT, etc.)\n- Lexicon and grammar acquisition and induction\n- Hybrid approaches that integrate and unify aspects of rule-based MT and \n statistical MT\n- MT for resource-poor languages\n- MT on resource-limited machinery (e.g. PDAs)\n- Distributed architectures for large data MT\n- Speech-to-speech or speech-to-text MT\n- MT with OCR\n- MT for communication (chats, blogs, social networks)\n- Customization and adaptation of high-performance MT systems\n- Deep integration of MT technology within translation and localization\n pipelines\n- MT Evaluation\n\n\nSubmission Instructions:\n\nPapers should not be longer than 10 pages and should be in pdf format. Style\nfiles (Latex and MS Word) will be posted on the conference web-page at:\n\nhttp://amta2010.amtaweb.org/\n\nTo allow for blind reviewing, please do not include author names and\naffiliations within the paper and avoid obvious self-references.\n\nDetailed submission instructions will be posted on the conference website in\nthe near future and will be included in future announcements.\n\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nMT User Presentations: Commercial Users and Translators\n\nContact: Mike Dillinger ( mike@translationOptimization.com )\n \nThe Commercial User track will focus on how MT can meet business needs such as\njust-in-time localization of critical information, provisioning of technical\nsupport information, or creation of preliminary translations for post-editing.\nSubmissions should focus on the use of MT in a business setting and how it is\nintegrated with other technologies to support business goals. \n\n\nImportant dates:\n\n- Submissions due: Monday, June 28\n- Notification of acceptance:\t Monday, July 12\n- Final "camera-ready" versions due: Monday, August 16\n\n\nTopics of interest include but are not limited to:\n\n- Integrating MT and human translation \n- Post-editing experiences and data about productivity \n- ROI analyses of post-editing versus translation \n- Use of MT to provide localization of data-driven, dynamic, or user-specific \n information \n- Use of MT to reduce localization time and/or cost \n- Ways in which MT can be used to increase the scope of globalization projects \n- Managing change when implementing MT systems\n- Open-source and low-cost MT tools: are they realistic and is there a market\n for them?\n\n\nWhat to submit:\n\nIdeal presentations will clearly identify a business need and describe how MT\nmeets those needs, with a candid assessment of its strengths and limitations\nfor that particular usage. Submissions should be 250-500 word summaries and\nmay be sent directly in e-mail or as attachments in RTF format.\n \n\nHow to submit:\n\nSend submissions or questions by email to Mike Dillinger \n(mike@translationOptimization.com) by Monday, June 28.\n\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nMT User Presentations: Government Users and Translation Professionals\n\nContacts: Nick Bemish ( Nicholas.Bemish@dia.mil )\n Chuck Simmons ( Charles.Simmons@wpafb.af.mil )\n\n\nAMTA Government User presenters and participants will focus on the strategic\nnature and use of Machine Translation in governmental organizations. Most\ngovernmental entities are providing a benefit to their customers, who require\nthem to translate large volumes of information and to make it available across\nmultiple languages and varied network architectures. The need for language\ntranslation technology within governmental organizations is diverse and\nsometimes compartmented. Governments are looking to advances in Machine\nTranslation technology, which help them deliver information not only from the\nnative languages of various countries but also into those other languages. In\nturn, the information delivered helps the governments to understand social and\npolitical activities in context. In an age when significant volumes of data\nare available in many languages, it is necessary to look to automated\nalternatives, which assist the linguist and enable the human translation\nprocess.\n\nFor this year's AMTA conference, we are asking government participants to\nconsider topics that address the strategic challenges of applying MT tools and\napplications in their programs and processes. We are looking for\nrepresentation from all government organizations that face language\nchallenges, including: Defense, Homeland Security, Health and Human Services,\nHuman Resources, Commerce, Labor, Energy, Judiciary, Business, Trade,\nTransportation, and many others. Within the governmental organizations we\nrequest the attendance of leaders or their representatives, who can address\nchallenging topics ranging among:\n\n1. Acquisition strategies that include policies directed towards \n implementation of MT \n2. Funding priorities that stress the need for metrics to ensure adequate\n return on investment (ROI) \n3. Requirements development which include a broad audience of users across\n the federal workspace \n4. Computer systems and network architectures that support inclusion of MT\n tools and any significant integration and security challenges \n5. Research and development leading to the advancement of tools that support\n less commonly used languages or minimizes gaps \n6. Program management strategies and how they apply to the integration and\n acceptance of MT tool usage \n7. Case studies on examples of MT use and how it impacts the organizations\n ability to share content \n8. Strategic views and objectives pertaining to challenges with respect to MT\n programs and the employment of MT tools (e.g., IT, personnel,\n implementation) \n9. Implementation strategies that factor into MT use as a process supporting\n human translation (pre-translation/post-editing)\n\nThe sessions will be structured to provide open and constructive dialogue\namong attendees with diverse technical backgrounds and areas of expertise.\nA secondary objective of this approach is to establish longer-term\nconnections among participants and foster new cooperative efforts.\n\n\nImportant dates:\n\n- Submissions due: Monday, June 28\n- Notification of acceptance: Monday, July 12\n- Final "camera-ready" versions due: Monday, August 16\n\n\nWhat to submit:\n\nIdeal proposals should include information on strategic views and objectives\npertaining to MT programs; employment of MT tools and significant challenges;\nas well as information on achievable gains through usage and/or metrics.\nSubmissions should be 250-400 word summaries and may be sent directly in\ne-mail or as attachments in RTF format.\n\n\nHow to submit:\n\nSend submissions and questions to Government User program chairs, Nicholas\nBemish at Nicholas.Bemish@dia.mil and Chuck Simmons at\nCharles.Simmons@wpafb.af.mil by Monday, June 28.\n\n \n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nStudent Research Workshop\n\nContact: Stephan Vogel ( stephan.vogel@cs.cmu.edu )\n\nAMTA-2010 will feature a Student Research Workshop, which will be embedded as\nan integral part of the research program at the conference. Students at all\nlevels of study (undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate) are invited to\nsubmit papers describing their research work. To qualify, the main author of\nthe paper must be a student or a post-doc. Both completed work as well as\nwork in progress is eligible for submission. Submissions will be competitively\nreviewed by a committee consisting of both advanced MT students and senior\nresearchers, in a process similar to the reviewing of submissions to the main\nAMTA-2010 research program. We hope to provide travel and participation \nfinancial support to the students selected for presentations. Details will be\nposted on the conference website when available. \n \n\nImportant dates:\n\n- Submission deadline: Monday, May 24\n- Notifications of acceptance: Monday, July 5\n- Final "camera-ready" versions: Monday, August 16\n\n\nTopics:\n\nAll topics related to MT research are welcome. See the list of topics for the\nMT Research Program above for a listing of sample topics of interest.\n \n\nWhat to submit:\n\nPapers should not be longer than 10 pages, formatted using the provided style\nfor research papers, and in pdf format. Style files (Latex and MS Word) will\nbe posted on the conference web-page at:\n\nhttp://amta2010.amtaweb.org/\n\nTo allow for blind reviewing, please do not include author names and \naffiliations within the paper and avoid obvious self-references.\n\nDetailed submission instructions will be posted on the conference website in\nthe near future and will be included in future announcements.\n\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nCall for Proposals for Workshops, Tutorials and Panels at AMTA-2010\n\nContact: George Foster ( george.foster@nrc.gc.ca )\n\nAMTA 2010 is seeking proposals for workshops, tutorials and plenary panels on\nall topics related to MT. We particularly encourage proposals on topics\nrelated to the conference theme of MT applied within commercial translation\nsettings.\n\nTutorials will be held on Sunday, October 31, immediately preceding the main \nconference. Workshops will be held on Thursday and Friday, November 4-5,\nimmediately following the main conference. Selected panels will be an\nintegral part of the main conference.\n\n\nAims:\n\nTutorials at AMTA conferences are a forum for experts in MT and MT-related\nareas to deliver concentrated training on a topic of interest in half-day (or\noccasionally full-day) teaching sessions. Tutorials provide background that\nhelps conference participants (especially newcomers to the field) understand\nthe conference program, and/or enrich their understanding of particular\ntechnical, applied, and business matters surrounding research, development and\nuse of MT and translation technology.\n\nAMTA workshops are intended to provide the opportunity for MT-related\ncommunities of interest to spend focused time together advancing the state of\nthinking or the state of practice in their area of interest or endeavor. \n\nPanel sessions within the main conference program provide an opportunity for a\nselect number of experts to provide their perspective and hold a discussion on\na concrete topic of interest or developing issue within the field of MT.\n\nDue to AMTA 2010's collocation with the ATA meeting, we are particularly\ninterested in proposals related to commercialization of MT and/or its use by\nprofessional translators. However, any themes connected to MT research,\ndevelopment, deployment, use, and evaluation are welcome.\n\n\nWhat to submit:\n\nProposals for workshops, tutorials and panel sessions should be submitted by\nJune 30, 2010 to George Foster (george.foster@nrc.gc.ca). They should include\nthe proposed format (workshop, tutorial or panel), a title, a one-page\ndescription of the proposed content, technical requirements and the expected\nnumber of participants. In the case of a workshop, the proposal should also\ninclude dates for important milestones (call for papers, recruitment of\nspeakers, etc.), and whether this is an ongoing or new workshop. Workshop and\nTutorial proposals must also include a signed copy of the AMTA Workshop or\nTutorial Policy and Leader Agreement Form. The appropriate forms will be\nposted on the conference web-page at:\n\nhttp://amta2010.amtaweb.org/\n\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nCall for AMTA-2010 Sponsorships\n\nHelp support the AMTA Mission while demonstrating your leadership in the\nfuture of MT!\n\nSponsorship of AMTA-2010 is a tax-deductible donation. AMTA is a 501-(c)-3\nnon-profit educational association.\n\nAll sponsorship levels receive:\n- Logo with hyperlink to sponsor website on website: \n http://amta2010.amtaweb.org/\n- Logo and name in conference program\n- Acknowledgement at Conference Opening\n- One piece of collateral included in Conference Bag\n\nPlease contact Sponsorship Chair Laurie Gerber (lgerber@amtaweb.org) for a\nsponsorship prospectus. Help us provide continuous internet service for\nparticipants! Support a workshop! Snag the hottest brand real estate at the\nconference - the badgeholder! Several new sponsor-able items are available\nthis time, including your logo on the hotel room keys!\n\n---------------------------------------------------------------------------- (AMTA-2010, \n\n , The, Ninth, Biennial, Conference, of, \n , the, Association, for, Machine, Translation, in, the, Americas, \n\n , Westin, Tabor, Center, ,, Denver, ,, Colorado, \n , Held, , October, 31, -, November, 05, ,, 2010, \n\n\n , PRELIMINARY, ANNOUNCEMENT, and, CALL, FOR, PAPERS, \n\n , MACHINE, TRANSLATION, IN, THE, PRODUCTION, PIPELINE, \n\n, The, ninth, biennial, conference, of, the, Association, for, Machine, Translation, \n, in, the, Americas, (, AMTA-2010, ), will, be, held, at, the, Westin, Tabor, Center, in, \n, Denver, Colorado, ,, Sunday, ,, October, 31, through, Friday, ,, November, 5, ., , AMTA-2010, will, take, place, immediately, following, the, 51st, Annual, Conference, ...) Denver [AMTA-2010, The Ninth Biennial Conference of, the Association for Machine Translation in the Americas, Westin Tabor Center, Denver, Colorado, Held October 31 - November 05, 2010, PRELIMINARY ANNOUNCEMENT and CALL FOR PAPERS, MACHINE TRANSLATION IN THE PRODUCTION PIPELINE, The ninth biennial conference of the Association for Machine Translation, in the Americas (AMTA-2010) will be held at the Westin Tabor Center in, Denver Colorado, Sunday, October 31 through Friday, November 5, AMTA-2010 will take place immediately following the 51st Annual Conference of the, American Translators Association (ATA), also taking place in Denver,, October 27-30, The two conferences are planning multiple coordinated, events around joint topics of interest, These are designed to deepen MT, researchers' and developers' understanding of the needs of the commercial, translation industry and human translators, while also fostering, translators' understanding of modern MT technology and the role of, advanced translation automation in commercial translation processes., In addition to a research track, the main AMTA-2010 conference program, will include presentation tracks for government and commercial users of MT, and a "Technology Showcase" of commercial and research-stage MT, technology, The research program will include a peer-reviewed competitive "Student Research Workshop" designed to highlight and foster the work of, the next generation of MT researchers, Tutorials will be held on Sunday,, October 31, and workshops will take place primarily on Thursday and, Friday, November 4-5., ----------------------------------------------------------------------------, Call for MT Research Papers at AMTA-2010, Contact: Hassan Sawaf (hassan (at) sawaf.de), Machine Translation continues to be one of the most active research areas, within Natural Language Processing, MT evaluations, such as those, conducted by NIST, provide ample evidence that the field of MT continues, to grow and attract more and more researchers, Data-driven approaches, have become particularly fashionable in recent years, These approaches, have generated systems that have been the top performers in recent, comparative evaluations, Furthermore, the challenges of building, competitive MT systems have been significantly reduced with the, introduction of open source toolkits such as GIZA++ and MOSES, This, development, exciting as it is, also bears the danger of introducing, uniformity into MT research, AMTA aims to promote diversity in MT, research and actively seeks research papers across the entire range of the MT research spectrum for the AMTA-2010 research program, We solicit, submissions in English of unpublished papers describing original research, on all aspects of Machine Translation, We particularly encourage, submissions on topics related to the conference theme of MT applied within commercial translation settings., Important dates:, - Submission deadline: Monday, May 24, - Notifications of acceptance: Monday, July 5, - Final "camera-ready" versions: Monday, August 16, Topics of interest include but are not limited to:, - Advances in data-driven MT (Statistical MT, Example-based MT, etc.), - Advances in rule-based MT (Transfer-based MT, Interlingual MT, etc.), - Lexicon and grammar acquisition and induction, - Hybrid approaches that integrate and unify aspects of rule-based MT and, statistical MT, - MT for resource-poor languages, - MT on resource-limited machinery (e.g, PDAs), - Distributed architectures for large data MT, - Speech-to-speech or speech-to-text MT, - MT with OCR, - MT for communication (chats, blogs, social networks), - Customization and adaptation of high-performance MT systems, - Deep integration of MT technology within translation and localization, pipelines, - MT Evaluation, Submission Instructions:, Papers should not be longer than 10 pages and should be in pdf format, Style files (Latex and MS Word) will be posted on the conference web-page, at:, http://amta2010.amtaweb.org/, To allow for blind reviewing, please do not include author names and, affiliations within the paper and avoid obvious self-references., Detailed submission instructions will be posted on the conference website, in the near future and will be included in future announcements., ----------------------------------------------------------------------------, MT User Presentations: Commercial Users and Translators, Contact: Mike Dillinger ( mike@translationOptimization.com ), The Commercial User track will focus on how MT can meet business needs, such as just-in-time localization of critical information, provisioning of, technical support information, or creation of preliminary translations for post-editing, Submissions should focus on the use of MT in a business, setting and how it is integrated with other technologies to support, business goals., Important dates:, - Submissions due: Monday, June 28, - Notification of acceptance: Monday, July 12, - Final "camera-ready" versions due: Monday, August 16, Topics of interest include but are not limited to:, - Integrating MT and human translation, ...] The Ninth Biennial Conference of {'October 27-30': 'translators association (ata), also taking place in denver, october 27-30.', 'Sunday': ' tutorials will be held on sunday,', 'October 31': 'october 31, and workshops will take place primarily on thursday and', 'Thursday': ' workshops will be held on thursday and friday, november 4-5,', 'Monday': '- submission deadline: monday, may 24', 'May 24': '- submission deadline: monday, may 24', 'Monday, July 5': '- notifications of acceptance: monday, july 5', 'Monday, August 16': '- final "camera-ready" versions: monday, august 16', 'Monday, June 28': 'charles.simmons@wpafb.af.mil by monday, june 28.', 'Monday, July 12': '- notification of acceptance: monday, july 12', 'Sunday, October 31': 'tutorials will be held on sunday, october 31, immediately preceding the main ', 'Friday, November': ' workshops will be held on thursday and friday, november', 'June 30, 2010': 'june 30, 2010 to george foster (george.foster@nrc.gc.ca)'}
86 4th International Workshop on Architectures, Concepts and Technologies for Service Oriented Computing Athens, Greece CALL FOR PAPERS\n===================================================================\n\n 4th International Workshop on\n Architectures, Concepts and Technologies for \n Service Oriented Computing - ACT4SOC\n http://www.icsoft.org/ACT4SOC.htm\n\n23 July, 2010 - Athens, Greece \n\nHeld in conjunction with Fifth International Conference on Software and Data Technologies - ICSOFT 2010\n\nIn cooperation with IICREST and SEEKDA\n\nDeadline for workshop paper submissions: 30 April 2010 [extended]\n\nINTRODUCTION\nService-Oriented Computing (SOC) has emerged as a new computing paradigm for designing, building and using software applications to support business processes in heterogeneous, distributed and continuously changing environments. The architectural foundation for SOC is provided by the Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA), which states that applications expose their functionality as services in a uniform and technology-independent way such that they can be discovered and invoked over the network. Claimed benefits of SOC include cheaper and faster development of business applications through repeated aggregation of services, better reuse of software artifacts and legacy applications through service wrappings, and easier adaptation to changes in the business environment through replacement and reconfiguration of services.\n\nIn order to realize these benefits routinely with SOC, for realistic business settings with complex IT environments, many challenges still need to be addressed. For example, supporting business processes and collaborations in an open service-oriented world requires a better understanding of integration problems along different dimensions. First of all, alignment between business demands and application functions has to be achieved. This requirement for vertical integration should drive the aggregation of services, from basic IT services to rich business services, to achieve the desired or given business processes. Secondly, horizontal integration has to be considered if business collaborations span multiple organizations. In such cases, interoperability between the services has to be ensured at different levels (syntactic, semantic and pragmatic) and on different aspects (information and behavior). Thirdly, we have to assume that business demands as well as IT capabilities will change over time. This evolution will impact existing solutions, and thus require the adaptation, management and maintenance (e.g., versioning, replacing, updating) of services and service compositions. Moreover, changes that occur at one level or on one aspect have to be propagated to other levels and aspects in order to keep the consistency of the integration solution. And finally, all of the above challenges not only exist at design-time, but at run-time as well. Service composition may be on-demand, driven by an end-user service creation activity, and running instances of composite services are subject to changes concerning, for instance, the availability of resources. This implies that service level agreements and associated quality-of-service need to be negotiated, monitored, and controlled in multi-party and heterogeneous environments.\n\nGOAL AND TOPICS\nThe goal of the workshop is to focus on the fundamental and practical challenges related to SOC, to discuss what theoretical, architectural or technology foundation is needed, and how this foundation can be supported or realized by new or enhanced infrastructures, standards and/or technologies. The workshop aims at contributing to the dissemination of research results, establishment of a better understanding, and identification of new challenges related to SOC/SOA, by bringing together interested academic and industrial researchers. \n\nTopics of interest for the workshop include, but are not limited to:\n\nService foundation and design issues\n\t- principles of SOC/SOA, service science\n\t- service modelling approaches\n\t- formal specification and analysis\n\t- reasoning approaches\n\t- model-driven development, platform-independence\n\t- service interoperability (semantic, pragmatic), matching and (dynamic) composition\n\t- ontology-centered design\n\t- requirements-functionality (business-IT) alignment \n\t- Web 2.0, social networking, mash-ups\n\t- REST vs WS\n\t- repeated aggregation of services into composite applications and business processes\n\nService technology and infrastructure issues\n\t- architectural patterns\n\t- service registry management\n\t- requirements management, service evolution\n\t- quality-of-service management\n\t- cross-domain service delivery\n\t- specific technology platform solutions\n\t- language-specific solutions\n\t- tool support\n\t- applicability and performance experiences\n\t- service level agreements\n\nService usage issues and applications of SOC/SOA\n\t- service registration, update, de-registration\n\t- service discovery, matching, selection, replacement\n\t- service invocation, interaction, monitoring\n\t- service choreography, mediation, orchestration\n\t- traceability of technology changes in requirements and vice versa\n\t- mobile and ubiquitous applications\n\t- health and homecare applications\n\t- supply chain management applications\n\t- e-commerce applications\n\t- experiences regarding SOC in industrial and real-world applications\n\nPUBLICATION\nAll accepted papers will be published in a workshop proceedings book, under an ISBN reference, and in CD-ROM support. The proceedings will be indexed by DBLP. Best papers of the workshop will be considered for inclusion in a book edited and published by Springer.\n\nINFORMATION FOR AUTHORS\nProspective authors are invited to submit papers in any of the topics listed above. Instructions for preparing the manuscript (in Word and Latex formats) are available at the conference Paper Templates web page. Please also check the web page with the Submission Guidelines.\nPapers should be submitted electronically via the web-based submission system at: http://www.insticc.org/Primoris.\n\nREGISTRATION INFORMATION\nAt least one author of an accepted paper must register for the workshop. If the registration fees are not received by May 19, 2010, the paper will not be published in the workshop proceedings book.\n\nIMPORTANT DATES\nPaper submissions due: April 6, 2010\nNotification to authors: May 4, 2010\nCamera ready due and registration: May 19, 2010\n\nCHAIRS\nMarten van Sinderen, University of Twente, Netherlands Brahmananda Sapkota, University of Twente, Netherlands\n\nPROGRAM COMMITEE\nMarco Aiello, University of Groningen, Netherlands \nMarkus Aleksy, ABB Corporate Research, Germany \nColin Atkinson, University of Mannheim, Germany \nSami Bhiri, Digital Enterprise Research Institute, Ireland \nBarrett Bryant, Univ. of Alabama at Birmington, USA \nKuo-Ming. Chao, Coventry University, UK \nRemco Dijkman, University of Eindhoven, Netherlands \nClever de Farias, University of Sao Paulo, Brazil \nWalid Gaaloul, Institut Telecom, France \nArmin Haller, CSRIO, Australian National University, Australia \nManfred Hauswirth, Digital Enterprise Research Institute, Ireland \nJuan Miguel Gomez, Universidad Carlos III de Madrid, Spain \nAdrian Mocan, SAP, Germany \nIvan Ivanov, SUNY Empire State College, USA \nDimitris Karagiannis, University of Vienna, Austria \nHaklae Kim, Samsung, Korea \nMichael Parkin, University of Tilburg, Netherlands \nDick Quartel, Telematica Instituut, Netherlands \nDumitru Roman, SINTEF, Norway \nTony Shan, Keane Inc., USA \nBoris Shishkov, INSTICC / University of Delft, Netherlands \nKen Turner, University of Stirling, UK \nTomas Vitvar, University of Innsbruck, Austria \nMichal Zaremba, Seekda, Austria\n\nSECRETARIAT CONTACTS\nICSOFT Workshops - ACT4SOC 2010\ne-mail: icsoft.workshops.secretariat@insticc.org ( , CALL, FOR, PAPERS, \n, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, \n\n , 4th, International, Workshop, on, \n , Architectures, ,, Concepts, and, Technologies, for, \n , Service, Oriented, Computing, -, ACT4SOC, \n , http://www.icsoft.org/ACT4SOC.htm, \n\n, 23, July, ,, 2010, -, Athens, ,, ...) Athens [ CALL FOR PAPERS, ===================================================================, 4th International Workshop on, Architectures, Concepts and Technologies for , Service Oriented Computing - ACT4SOC, http://www.icsoft.org/ACT4SOC.htm, 23 July, 2010 - Athens, Greece , Held in conjunction with Fifth International Conference on Software and Data Technologies - ICSOFT 2010, In cooperation with IICREST and SEEKDA, Deadline for workshop paper submissions: 30 April 2010 [extended], INTRODUCTION, Service-Oriented Computing (SOC) has emerged as a new computing paradigm for designing, building and using software applications to support business processes in heterogeneous, distributed and continuously changing environments, The architectural foundation for SOC is provided by the Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA), which states that applications expose their functionality as services in a uniform and technology-independent way such that they can be discovered and invoked over the network, Claimed benefits of SOC include cheaper and faster development of business applications through repeated aggregation of services, better reuse of software artifacts and legacy applications through service wrappings, and easier adaptation to changes in the business environment through replacement and reconfiguration of services., In order to realize these benefits routinely with SOC, for realistic business settings with complex IT environments, many challenges still need to be addressed, For example, supporting business processes and collaborations in an open service-oriented world requires a better understanding of integration problems along different dimensions, First of all, alignment between business demands and application functions has to be achieved, This requirement for vertical integration should drive the aggregation of services, from basic IT services to rich business services, to achieve the desired or given business processes, Secondly, horizontal integration has to be considered if business collaborations span multiple organizations, In such cases, interoperability between the services has to be ensured at different levels (syntactic, semantic and pragmatic) and on different aspects (information and behavior), Thirdly, we have to assume that business demands as well as IT capabilities will change over time, This evolution will impact existing solutions, and thus require the adaptation, management and maintenance (e.g., versioning, replacing, updating) of services and service compositions, Moreover, changes that occur at one level or on one aspect have to be propagated to other levels and aspects in order to keep the consistency of the integration solution, And finally, all of the above challenges not only exist at design-time, but at run-time as well, Service composition may be on-demand, driven by an end-user service creation activity, and running instances of composite services are subject to changes concerning, for instance, the availability of resources, This implies that service level agreements and associated quality-of-service need to be negotiated, monitored, and controlled in multi-party and heterogeneous environments., GOAL AND TOPICS, The goal of the workshop is to focus on the fundamental and practical challenges related to SOC, to discuss what theoretical, architectural or technology foundation is needed, and how this foundation can be supported or realized by new or enhanced infrastructures, standards and/or technologies, The workshop aims at contributing to the dissemination of research results, establishment of a better understanding, and identification of new challenges related to SOC/SOA, by bringing together interested academic and industrial researchers, Topics of interest for the workshop include, but are not limited to:, Service foundation and design issues, \t- principles of SOC/SOA, service science, \t- service modelling approaches, \t- formal specification and analysis, \t- reasoning approaches, \t- model-driven development, platform-independence, \t- service interoperability (semantic, pragmatic), matching and (dynamic) composition, \t- ontology-centered design, \t- requirements-functionality (business-IT) alignment , \t- Web 2.0, social networking, mash-ups, \t- REST vs WS, \t- repeated aggregation of services into composite applications and business processes, Service technology and infrastructure issues, \t- architectural patterns, \t- service registry management, \t- requirements management, service evolution, \t- quality-of-service management, \t- cross-domain service delivery, \t- specific technology platform solutions, \t- language-specific solutions, \t- tool support, \t- applicability and performance experiences, \t- service level agreements, Service usage issues and applications of SOC/SOA, \t- service registration, update, de-registration, \t- service discovery, matching, selection, replacement, \t- service invocation, interaction, monitoring, \t- service choreography, mediation, orchestration, \t- traceability of technology changes in requirements and vice versa, \t- mobile and ubiquitous applications, \t- health and homecare applications, \t- supply chain management applications, \t- e-commerce applications, \t- experiences regarding SOC in industrial and real-world applications, PUBLICATION, All accepted papers will be published in a workshop proceedings book, under an ISBN reference, and in CD-ROM support, The proceedings will be indexed by DBLP, Best papers of the workshop will be considered for inclusion in a book edited and published by Springer., INFORMATION FOR AUTHORS, Prospective authors are invited to submit papers in any of the topics listed above, Instructions for preparing the manuscript (in Word and Latex formats) are available at the conference Paper Templates web page, Please also check the web page with the Submission 87 LREC 2010 Workshop on Web Logs and Question Answering Valletta, Malta CALL FOR PAPERS\n\nLREC 2010 Workshop on Web Logs and Question Answering\n\nValletta, Malta, Saturday 22nd May 2010\n\nwww.csis.ul.ie/wlqa2010\n\nSubmission deadline: 12th February 2010\n\nMotivation & Scope\n==================\n\nAn Information Retrieval system takes a user query and returns a ranked list\nof documents. On the other hand, a Question Answering system provides an\nexact answer [1]. There has been quite a long period of research in factoid\nQA driven by annual tracks at CLEF [2], TREC [3] and NTCIR [4]. The result\nof this work has been that it is possible to construct systems which can\nanswer simple factoid queries with high accuracy. This has led to the belief\nthat QA is a "solved problem" where no more research is required. However,\nthe questions are not usually from real users, they are devised by the\nassessors at CLEF, TREC etc. Secondly, they are restricted to certain\nwell-known simple types which are only a small subset of the real questions\nwhich people wish to ask. Thirdly, questions are considered in isolation (or\nin some tracks a fixed group) and not in a dialogue context whereas in our\ninteractions with people all questions are answered in context and with the\npossibility for clarification. Thus, there is a need to inject new ideas\ninto QA research.\n\nRecently there has been much interest in Web query logs and in particular\nmethods for analysing these in order to extract information which can be\nused to improve IR systems [5,6]. Logs are typically extremely large and\ncontain naturally occurring and noisy data. Automatic techniques (using for\nexample statistical approaches or machine learning algorithms) are therefore\nnecessary since manual approaches are not generally feasible.\n\nThe purpose of the workshop, therefore, is to investigate how some of the\nmethods developed for analysing web logs within an implicit IR context can\nbe applied to QA. For example:\n\n* Can the meaning of IR queries in logs be deduced automatically in order to\nextract the corresponding questions from them?\n\n* Can NLP techniques developed within QA, e.g. Named Entity recognition be\napplied to the analysis of query logs?\n\n* Can logs be used to deduce useful new forms of question (i.e. not simple\nfactoids) which could be looked at next by QA researchers?\n\n* Can questions grouped into sessions be comprehended in such a way as to\ndeduce the underlying implicit natural language dialogue consisting of a\ncoherent sequence of questions where each follows logically from both the\nprevious ones and the system's responses to them?\n\n* Are there logs from real (or experimental) QA systems like lexxe.com which\ncan be obtained and what can be learned from them from the perspective of\ndesigning evaluation tasks? What about logs from sites like answers.com\n(where queries are answered by human respondents)?\n\n* Are QA query logs different from IR query logs? Do users behave\ndifferently in QA systems? Can QA-style questions be identified within an IR\nlog?\n\n* Can click-through data - where the aim of a question can be inferred from\nthe returned documents which are inspected - be used for the development of\nQA systems for example for the deduction of important query types and their\nlinks to IR queries?\n\n* Are there logs of transcribed speech made from telephone QA systems which\ncan be obtained and what analysis could be carried out on those, using for\nexample techniques developed at related tracks at CLEF such as\nCross-Language Speech Retrieval (CL-SR) and Question Answering on Script\nTranscription (QAST)?\n\nHistorically, QA was a combination of NLP and IR. Much web log analysis is a\nform of IR in which the same problem of retrieval is being approached from a\ndifferent direction, namely the queries themselves. Thus we are proposing\nhere a new combination, namely QA and log analysis. These fields are\ncomplementary and share the goal of building better systems for users.\n\n1. Prager, J. (2006). Open-Domain Question Answering (2006). Foundations and\n Trends in Information Retrieval, 1 (2), 1-141.\n2. CLEF (2009). http://www.clef-campaign.org. Accessed 2009.\n3. TREC (2009). http://trec.nist.gov/. Accessed 2009.\n4. NTCIR (2009). http://research.nii.ac.jp/ntcir/. Accessed 2009.\n5. Jansen, J., Taksa, I., & Spink, A. (eds.) (2008). Handbook of Web Log\n Analysis. Hershey, PA: IGI Global.\n6. QLA Workshop (2009). http://ir.shef.ac.uk/cloughie/qlaw2009.\n\nSubmissions\n===========\n\nAuthors are invited to submit original research papers addressing questions\non the lines listed above. Papers must be related to QA and must involve the\nuse of a query log (but not necessarily of a QA system). Submissions will be\nreviewed by members of the programme committee and judged on technical\nquality, clarity and relevance to the workshop.\n\nPapers should be no longer than 8 pages, set in accordance with LREC\nguidelines and using the LaTeX or Word templates which are available here:\nhttp://www.lrec-conf.org/lrec2010/?Author-s-Kit-and-Templates\n\nPapers should be submitted in pdf via the WLQA2010 START system:\nhttps://www.softconf.com/lrec2010/WLQA2010/ . When using START, authors will\nbe asked to provide essential information about resources (in a broad sense,\ni.e. also technologies, standards, evaluation kits, etc.) that have been\nused for the work described in the paper or are a new result of your\nresearch. For further information on this new iniative, please refer to\nhttp://www.lrec-conf.org/lrec2010/?LREC2010-Map-of-Language-Resources\n\nProceedings will be produced at the workshop and it is intended that\nselected papers will be published in a journal special issue after LREC has\ntaken place.\n\nImportant Dates\n===============\n\n1st Call for Papers: December 2009\nSecond Call for Papers: January 2010\nSubmission deadline: 12th February 2010\nNotification of acceptance: 12th March 2010 Final versions of papers: 19th\nMarch 2010\nWorkshop: At LREC, Saturday 22nd May 2010\n\nOrganisers\n==========\n\nRichard Sutcliffe\nUniversity of Limerick\nRichard.Sutcliffe at ul dot ie\n\nUdo Kruschwitz\nUniversity of Essex\nudo at essex dot ac dot uk\n\nThomas Mandl\nUniversity of Hildesheim\nmandl at uni-hildesheim dot de\n\nProgramme Committee\n===================\n\nBettina Berendt\nKatholieke Universiteit Leuven, Belgium\n\nGosse Bouma\nRijksuniversiteit Groningen, The Netherlands\n\nPaul Clough\nUniversity of Sheffield, UK\n\nGiorgio Di Nunzio\nUniversity of Padoa, Italy\n\nJim Jansen\nPennsylvania State University, USA\n\nJohannes Leveling\nDublin City University, Ireland\n\nFabrizio Silvestri\nISTI-CNR, Italy\n\nTomek Strzalkowski\nSUNY Albany, USA\n\nJosÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ© Luis Vicedo\nUniversity of Alicante, Spain\n\nKieran White\nUniversity of Limerick, Ireland (CALL, FOR, PAPERS, \n\n, LREC, 2010, Workshop, on, Web, Logs, and, Question, Answering, \n\n, Valletta, ,, Malta, ,, Saturday, 22nd, May, 2010, \n\n, www.csis.ul.ie, /, wlqa2010, \n\n, Submission, deadline, :, 12th, February, 2010, \n\n, Motivation, &, Scope, \n, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, =, \n, exact, answer, [, 1, ], ., There, has, been, quite, a, long, period, of, ...) Valletta [CALL FOR PAPERS, LREC 2010 Workshop on Web Logs and Question Answering, Valletta, Malta, Saturday 22nd May 2010, www.csis.ul.ie/wlqa2010, Submission deadline: 12th February 2010, Motivation & Scope, ==================, An Information Retrieval system takes a user query and returns a ranked list, of documents, On the other hand, a Question Answering system provides an, exact answer [1], There has been quite a long period of research in factoid, QA driven by annual tracks at CLEF [2], TREC [3] and NTCIR [4], The result, of this work has been that it is possible to construct systems which can, answer simple factoid queries with high accuracy, This has led to the belief, that QA is a "solved problem" where no more research is required, However,, the questions are not usually from real users, they are devised by the, assessors at CLEF, TREC etc, Secondly, they are restricted to certain, well-known simple types which are only a small subset of the real questions, which people wish to ask, Thirdly, questions are considered in isolation (or, in some tracks a fixed group) and not in a dialogue context whereas in our, interactions with people all questions are answered in context and with the, possibility for clarification, Thus, there is a need to inject new ideas, into QA research., Recently there has been much interest in Web query logs and in particular, methods for analysing these in order to extract information which can be, used to improve IR systems [5,6], Logs are typically extremely large and, contain naturally occurring and noisy data, Automatic techniques (using for, example statistical approaches or machine learning algorithms) are therefore, necessary since manual approaches are not generally feasible., The purpose of the workshop, therefore, is to investigate how some of the, methods developed for analysing web logs within an implicit IR context can, be applied to QA, For example:, * Can the meaning of IR queries in logs be deduced automatically in order to, extract the corresponding questions from them?, * Can NLP techniques developed within QA, e.g, Named Entity recognition be, applied to the analysis of query logs?, * Can logs be used to deduce useful new forms of question (i.e, not simple, factoids) which could be looked at next by QA researchers?, * Can questions grouped into sessions be comprehended in such a way as to, deduce the underlying implicit natural language dialogue consisting of a, coherent sequence of questions where each follows logically from both the, previous ones and the system's responses to them?, * Are there logs from real (or experimental) QA systems like lexxe.com which, can be obtained and what can be learned from them from the perspective of, designing evaluation tasks? What about logs from sites like answers.com, (where queries are answered by human respondents)?, * Are QA query logs different from IR query logs? Do users behave, differently in QA systems? Can QA-style questions be identified within an IR, log?, * Can click-through data - where the aim of a question can be inferred from, the returned documents which are inspected - be used for the development of, QA systems for example for the deduction of important query types and their, links to IR queries?, * Are there logs of transcribed speech made from telephone QA systems which, can be obtained and what analysis could be carried out on those, using for, example techniques developed at related tracks at CLEF such as, Cross-Language Speech Retrieval (CL-SR) and Question Answering on Script, Transcription (QAST)?, Historically, QA was a combination of NLP and IR, Much web log analysis is a, form of IR in which the same problem of retrieval is being approached from a, different direction, namely the queries themselves, Thus we are proposing, here a new combination, namely QA and log analysis, These fields are, complementary and share the goal of building better systems for users., 1, Prager, J, (2006), Open-Domain Question Answering (2006), Foundations and, Trends in Information Retrieval, 1 (2), 1-141., 2, CLEF (2009), http://www.clef-campaign.org, Accessed 2009., 3, TREC (2009), http://trec.nist.gov/, Accessed 2009., 4, NTCIR (2009), http://research.nii.ac.jp/ntcir/, Accessed 2009., 5, Jansen, J., Taksa, I., & Spink, A, (eds.) (2008), Handbook of Web Log, ...] LREC 2010 Workshop on Web Logs and Question Answering {'Saturday 22nd May 2010': 'workshop: at lrec, saturday 22nd may 2010', '12th February 2010': 'submission deadline: 12th february 2010', 'December 2009': '1st call for papers: december 2009', 'January 2010': 'second call for papers: january 2010', '12th March 2010': 'notification of acceptance: 12th march 2010 final versions of papers: 19th', 'March 2010': 'march 2010'}
88 IEEE International Conference on Computational Intelligence for Measurement Systems and Applications Taranto, Italy 2010 IEEE International Conference on Computational Intelligence for Measurement Systems and Applications\n\nTaranto, Italy, 6-8 September 2010\n\nSponsored by the IEEE Instrumentation and Measurement Society\nand the IEEE Computational Intelligence Society\n\nOrganized by the IEEE CIS ISATC Task Force on Intelligent Measurement Systems,\nthe IEEE IMS TC-22 on Intelligent Measurement Systems, and the IEEE IMS TC-30 on Security and Contraband Detection\n\nThe wide and increasing needs of adaptable and flexible solutions for many industrial, environmental, and engineering applications point out the importance of using design methodologies and implementation technologies with high ability of adaptation and evolution. Soft computing is one of the most relevant answers to such needs: neural networks, fuzzy logic, and genetic/evolutionary algorithms are fundamental keys to tackle these difficult problems. On the other hand, accuracy and uncertainty issues as well as suited data acquisition systems must be carefully considered in these applications since the quality of the solution greatly relies on them. Up to now, analysis and experiments have been performed by scientists and practitioners mainly to understand the underlying technologies and methodologies, but without any specific focus on the mandatory need of a quantitative assessment and a metrological analysis. Measurement science and technologies are in fact vital to ensure the correct and effective use of soft computing technologies in real environments. CIMSA 2010 will continue the exciting experience of the previous editions by filling this gap in knowledge and practice, by focusing on the quantitative aspect of measurement issues for industrial, environmental, and engineering applications.\n\nPapers are solicited on all aspects of computational intelligence technologies for measurement systems and the related applications, from the points of view of both theory and practice. This includes but is not limited to: intelligent measurement systems; accuracy and precision of neural and fuzzy components; intelligent sensor fusion; intelligent monitoring and control systems; neural and fuzzy technologies for identification, prediction, and control of complex dynamic systems; evolutionary monitoring and control; neural and fuzzy signal/image processing for industrial and environmental applications; image understanding and recognition; soft-computing technologies for robotics and vision; soft computing technologies for medical and bioengineering applications; hybrid systems; fuzzy and neural components for embedded systems; hardware implementation of neural and fuzzy systems for measurements; neural, fuzzy and genetic/evolutionary algorithms for system optimization and calibration; neural and fuzzy diagnosis of components and systems; reliability of fuzzy and neural components; fault tolerance and testing in fuzzy and neural components; neural and fuzzy techniques for quality measurement.\n\nSUBMIT EXTENDED ABSTRACTS OR DRAFT PAPERS BY 15 APRIL 2010\nDetails for the submission and all information concerning the symposium can be found at the symposium here. Acceptance/rejection will be emailed by 28 May 2010. The final manuscript is due by 1 July 2010. Submission implies willingness to register at the conference, pay the registration fee and present the paper. Papers will be included in the proceedings only if at least one author will register and pay the registration fee by 1 July 2010 (member and non-member fees only are acceptable to this purpose) - no exceptions. If an author covers more than one paper with her/his registration to guarantee inclusion in the proceedings, she/he must pay a 50 US$ surcharge for each paper in excess of one. (2010, IEEE, International, Conference, on, Computational, Intelligence, for, Measurement, Systems, and, Applications, \n\n, Taranto, ,, Italy, ,, 6, -, 8, September, 2010, \n\n, Sponsored, by, the, IEEE, Instrumentation, and, Measurement, Society, \n, and, the, IEEE, Computational, Intelligence, Society, \n\n, Organized, by, the, IEEE, CIS, ISATC, Task, Force, on, Intelligent, Measurement, Systems, ,, \n, the, IEEE, IMS, TC-22, on, Intelligent, Measurement, Systems, ,, and, the, IEEE, IMS, TC-30, on, Security, and, Contraband, Detection, \n\n, The, wide, and, increasing, needs, of, adaptable, and, flexible, solutions, for, many, industrial, ,, environmental, ,, and, engineering, applications, point, out, the, importance, of, using, design, methodologies, ...)
